characters: BACK TO THE VILLA DI ROMA
BACK TO THE DEAUVILLE HOTEL SUITE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a young man’s hand with the same gold and diamond encrusted watch and diamond pinky ring raise a gun at an unseen target.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (IN SYNC)
dialogues.text: «+. until I wasn’t anymore...  TWO QUICK GUNSHOTS to the back of an UNKNOWN MAN’S head. The blank wall explodes in red, as though a bucket of blood had been thrown against it. The blood begins to slowly ooze down the wall covering it with red streaks.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (IN SYNC)
dialogues.text: .-. And started painting houses myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BACK in the ASSISTED LIVING FACILITY, Frank gives us a moment to grasp what he’s said. Then:

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: In this particular matter, the whole thing was built around the wedding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wedding invitation sits on a bureau next to Frank’s gold watch.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (IN SYNC)
dialogues.text: Bill Bufalino’s daughter was getting married in Detroit. Frank puts the watch on his wrist. The gold ring is on his finger next to his wedding band. He’s quite a bit younger than when we saw him at the assisted living facility. About 55.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (IN SYNC)
dialogues.text: Bill was a Teamster lawyer, but more important, he was Russell Bufalino’s cousin. He zips a suit and shirt into a garment bag like a body in a body bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank arranges luggage in the trunk of his black Lincoln Continental, leaving a space for more.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Russell didn’t want to fly. He wanted to take care of some business along the way. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Business in Russell's case means one thing: collecting money. So we'd drive. Him and his wife Carrie and me and Irene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While his wife Irene talks on the kitchen phone to Russell’s wife Carrie about what to wear, Frank marks towns on a AAA map of the eastern states that he knows Russell will want to stop.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: We'd take 476 out of Philly up to Pittston - then I-80 West through the rest of Pennsylvania - across Ohio to Toledo - then 75 North to Detroit. EXT. BUFALINO’S HOUSE - PITTSTON, PA - DAY - 1975 Irene and Carrie smoke cigarettes on the sidewalk outside a modest suburban house while Frank and Russell Bufalino add his and his wife’s luggage to the trunk. Russell’s about 15 years older than Frank.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: It was gonna take three days with all the business breaks and cigarette stops since Russell didn’t allow smoking in the car. He says Jimmy Blue Eyes and Meyer Lansky convinced him to stop when they were getting kicked out of their casinos in Cuba and getting shot at by Castro. I don’t know. It might have been one of those: “Please-God-if-I-ever-get-out-of- this-alive-I'1l-never-smoke-again- things”, but I do know that from Castro on Russ wouldn’t let anybody smoke in the car, even Carrie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank drives along a city street with Russell in front, the women in back, Carrie putting on some lipstick.

dialogues.speaker: CARRIE
dialogues.text: Can we stop soon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We’re not even to the highway.

dialogues.speaker: CARRIE
dialogues.text: You won't stop on the highway.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: It’s not safe to stop on the highway.

dialogues.speaker: CARRIE
dialogues.text: Then we'll smoke in the car.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: The smoke’s bad for my cataracts.

dialogues.speaker: CARRIE
dialogues.text: I’1l crack the window.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: Carrie - I made a vow.

dialogues.speaker: CARRIE
dialogues.text: And I can’t smoke in the car?

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: Or on the highway. Carrie isn’t having it; snaps open her little gold lamé cigarette clutch. She cracks the window. Russell glances over at Frank through his thick glasses and sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While Irene and Carrie sit on a guard rail smoking, Russell leans on the hood looking off at cars and trucks driving past. Frank comes over.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You see where we are?

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: What are the odds? They regard the unremarkable surroundings like they weren’t so unremarkable, including a Stuckey’s/Texaco gas station up the road. A tractor-trailer roars past and -

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. HIGHWAY I-80
dialogues.text: Frank, in his 30s, behind the wheel of a refrigerated truck.  He’s driving on the same highway he’1ll drive to Detroit on twenty-some years later with Russell and their wives, when the engine starts making noises it shouldn’t. Up ahead through the windshield is the same Stuckey’s-Texaco station - EXT. STUCKEY’S/TEXACO GAS STATION - I-80 - DAY - 1956 Frank has the truck’s hood open and is listening to the misfiring engine. He has a cloth tool kit, with various sized wrenches, open on the truck’s fender. Russell - who he doesn’t know yet - appears out of nowhere wearing no glasses.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: What’s the matter, kid?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Sounds funny. Frank runs the engine manually from under the hood as Russell listens.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: (finally) It’s your timing chain. He selects a wrench from Frank’s tools and makes an adjustment. In a few moments the engine is sounding normal again.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: This fix won’t last forever. Russell wipes his hands on a rag and heads off.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Jeezus! Thanks. What do I owe you? Russell waves back, ‘nothing,’ and Frank watches him walk into the gas station.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (IN SYNC)
dialogues.text: I thought maybe he owned the gas station. He owned something, you could tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank where we left him, in the wheelchair in the rec room with his aviator glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It turns out he owned the whole road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A priest performs a baptism. Frank and his first wife Mary’s second daughter, Peggy. There are so few people in attendance, it seems like a private ceremony. But it’s just they don’t have a lot of friends or relatives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “SKINNY RAZOR” swiftly runs his razor across a squawking chicken’s neck that gushes blood. Skinny then dumps the fluttering chicken head-first into a metal funnel to let it bleed out while grabbing his next victim.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Skinny Razor got the name because he started out as a kid killing live chickens at his father’s butcher shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A place called The Friendly Lounge according to its sign which has “STEAKS AND CHOPS” in neon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank hangs out with some other truck drivers, all Italians except him. Across the room at another table sits a group of mid-level mob guys, eating dinner. Indicating one of them -

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: That's Skinny Razor. He owns the place. He shylocks and runs a little book out of the joint. You should meet him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Did you say razor?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: He used to work at a butcher shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank's POV of Johnny talking to Skinny and gesturing for Frank to come over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and Johnny standing at Skinny’s table.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Skinny, this is Frank.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: You got something for me?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You like steak?

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: I own the joint don’t I?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I deliver steak.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: That’s what I hear.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I could deliver you steak. Johnny gives Skinny a nod that says “yes”.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: Have a drink. As the bartender serves drinks, Skinny toasts the group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's summer. As loading dock workers in short sleeves carry hindquarters and hang them in Frank’s refrigerated truck, he signs for the load - 25 beef carcasses.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: It’s harder to steal in the summer when the weather’s nice. He shuts the truck’s rear doors. The yard manager slaps an aluminum seal on the lock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank backs up to the store’s loading dock and climbs out as the store’s manager approaches with a clipboard and breaks the aluminum seal. Workers begin unloading the hindquarters, the store manager noting the number.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Winter’s a different story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same loading dock as before, but now it’s winter. Snow on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A heater glows in the yard manager’s dock office. Frank signs for 25 hindquarters.

dialogues.speaker: YARD MANAGER
dialogues.text: It's freezing out there.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I don’t mind it.

dialogues.speaker: YARD MANAGER
dialogues.text: Not me. I hate it. Will you do me a favor and put on the seal?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Sure. I’ve gotta be out there anyway. The Yard Manager hands Frank the aluminum seal, and turns away to warm his hands over a small floor heater.

dialogues.speaker: YARD MANAGER
dialogues.text: I owe you one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank emerges from the office, crosses the freezing cold dock, shuts the doors of the loaded truck but pockets the seal instead of putting it on the lock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skinny watches guys carry five hindquarters into the back of the Friendly Lounge as he pays Frank cash.  After the delivery is done and Skinny goes inside, Frank puts the seal on the truck door’s lock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The store MANAGER rubs his gloves together to restore some circulation and breaks the seal on the lock.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (to some dock guys) I’1l give you a hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank helps the dock workers carry the 20 (not 25) hindquarters to the store’s walk-in refrigerator. They hang them on one side and leave, but Frank stays behind and re-hangs five hindquarters that were already there on the other side to those he just delivered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back on the dock, the store manager signs for the shipment - 25 side of beef - and Frank hops back into his truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and Johnny and drivers at the bar with Christmas decorations. Skinny and mob friends eating Frank’s stolen steak. Skinny waves Frank over to the table.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: Delicious.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It's all Prime meat. I don’t go near “Choice”.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: Then keep’em coming, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another winter’s day. The store manager comes out to Frank’s truck and breaks the seal on the doors.  10

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: First I was stealing five hindquarters at a time. Then ten. Twelve. Things were missing everywhere I went. I was doing real good, but then - The doors open revealing no hindquarters inside. Frank looks mystified.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What the fuck?

dialogues.speaker: STORE MANAGER
dialogues.text: What the fuck is this?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I don’t know, it’s not my job to load. Maybe the loaders didn’t do their job. Everyone on the dock looks at Frank.

dialogues.speaker: STORE MANAGER
dialogues.text: You didn’t notice you were driving a light horse?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No, I thought I had a good horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The familiar two-horses-and-a-wheel International Brotherhood of Teamsters logo on the door of the Local.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: Under the contract, thanks to Jimmy Hoffa, management can only fire a driver on specific charges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank sits with Teamster lawyer Bill Bufalino, whose daughter's wedding Frank and Russell will drive across three states to attend 25 years later.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Ever show up late?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No.  11

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Any moving violations?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: You drink on the job?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Ever hit anybody?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: On the job?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No. The lawyer nods to himself - all this seems to be satisfactory to him - and he seems to have exhausted the list of fireable offenses.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Stealing isn’t grounds?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Can they prove it?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I don’t think so.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Then no. They regard each other.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: If they could prove it, all they’re going to want from you is names. Accomplices. You could keep your job and walk away. Would you give them names to keep your job?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No. Bill nods. That’s the right answer. Then -  12

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: You know I don’t care if you did it or not.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: It makes no difference to me. I’m here to defend you. Right?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: (whispers) But did you? Frank isn’t sure if he’s supposed to admit it or not to his lawyer. Eventually -

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I work hard for that company when I’m not stealing from them. Bill smiles. He likes Frank. He won’t be the last to appreciate his honest dishonesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the plaintiff's table - the Food Fair lawyers. At the defense table - Frank and his lawyer, Bill Bufalino, who addresses the judge -

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Your Honor, if this were about right and wrong, the company would have sought Mr. Sheeran’s dismissal. They didn’t. They only brought charges against Mr. Sheeran because the company hoped that he would name the conspirators he couldn’t give them because they don’t exist. They don’t exist because he never stole anything. He never stole anything because he’s an exemplary employee who in eight years has never taken a day of sick leave. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The only rule he ever broke was his own union’s, by helping others carry sides of beef from his truck to their refrigerators in the dead of winter. With that and all else he’s heard, the judge renders judgement -

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: I’m dismissing this case with a warning -

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yes, your Honor.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Not you, Mr. Sheeran. The plaintiff. You bring another workingman before this court with threats instead of evidence, believe me, you’ll be sorry. (shakes his head) If I owned stock in this company, I'd sell it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGELO BRUNO, humble-looking and simply dressed is seated at a table with Skinny Razor when Frank and Bill Bufalino walk in. Skinny whispers something to Bruno.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: I don’t know how he did it, and I’m not gonna ask. Angelo Bruno watches Frank walk from the entrance to the hat checking area with Bill Bufalino.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: All I know is that Bill Bufalino got me out of a case where I should’a gone down for the count. Angelo Bruno continues to watch as a WAITRESS helps Frank and Bill with their coats.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Instead, we went out celebrating and I met what was gonna turn out to be the rest of my life.  14 Bill Bufalino is surprised to see his cousin, RUSSELL BUFALINO, at the restaurant and headed for a table. Bill Bufalino acknowledges his cousin with a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Frank, this is my cousin, Russell Bufalino. Frank recognizes Russell Bufalino as the man who helped him with his truck.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (to Russell) Hey, didn’t you help me out with my truck a couple of months ago?

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: Yeah. It was nothing. It was that timing chain. They’re tricky. Did you get it fixed?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yeah. The next day. Thanks again.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: (teasing) Watch yourself with these tough guys around here. Alright, maybe I see you around. (You did the right thing.) A smiling Russell shakes hands with Frank and walks alone toward his own table as Bill and Frank are led to theirs.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (to Bill) Your cousin saved my ass. I could have lost the whole load.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Yeah. He knows everything about trucks. He worked for Canada Dry. Frank looks over to where Russell is being seated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank sees Russell Bufalino being seated at Angelo Bruno's table. Skinny Razor is gone. Bruno rises as Russell kisses Bruno’s cheek. Frank sees there are empty tables on either side of the Bruno table despite the restaurant being full with diners waiting.  15

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: I might not have known who Russell Bufalino was back then, but I had seen enough pictures and stories in the newspapers to know he was eating with Angelo Bruno, the new boss of Philadelphia, who ran everything from Philadelphia to Atlantic City. That was all I had to know that Russell Bufalino was no truck mechanic from Canada Dry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dinner’s over. Russell has joined Bill, Frank and Skinny Razor for coffee and anisette at Bill Bufalino’s table. Bill and Skinny Razor are talking about Skinny ducking a subpoena.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (Italian, subtitled) It’s very good bread. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: (Italian, subtitled) Where’d a Paddy learn to speak Italian?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (Italian, subtitled) In Sicily. The war. Russell is pleased and impressed with Frank's Italian, but even more so that he was in the war. They continue in Italian (wherever italicized) -

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Catania.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: I’m from Catania. How long?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Four years. 411 combat days. (in Italian) 122 at Anzio. (back to English) 45th Infantry.  16

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: It was bad there. Frank nods, but doesn’t elaborate.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: Did you think you’d die?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You think about it... you’re scared... but once the action starts, the fear goes away because you’re too busy fighting... I made it through the war so now, I look around... I think... what happens, happens.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: Fuck it. Russell nods, leaves it at that.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You got orders, you'd follow them. They tell you take some prisoners out to the woods - they don’t say “what to do” - they’d just say... like... “Hurry back”.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: That’s war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank holds a rifle on GERMAN SOLDIER #1 and #2 as they dig holes in the forest floor.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: You know it’s crazy but I never understood how they would just keep digging. Their own graves, y'know? Maybe they thought if they did a good job... the guy with the gun... German Soldiers #1 and #2 have finished digging and look up plaintively at Frank for mercy.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: +--+. would change his mind. Frank shoots the Germans. They fall into the hole.  17

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THE VILLA DI ROMA
dialogues.text: To Frank and Russell -

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: People cling to hope.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Russell took a shine to me. It wasn’t long before he had me doing little things for him and Angelo Bruno, himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The road ahead as the Lincoln drives a rural stretch of I-80 West.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Russell naps in the passenger seat while Frank drives, their wives in back.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Carrie’s family went back to the same town in Sicily as the Bufalinos. They talked about it all the time. She came from the Sciandras. To them it was like they came over on the Italian Mayflower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell comes in late at night through the back door into the darkened house. He’s surprised by Carrie who is still up. He’s got blood splattered on his shirt and face, which does not alarm her as it might most wives.

dialogues.speaker: CARRIE
dialogues.text: What happened? Russell gives her a look.

dialogues.speaker: CARRIE
dialogues.text: Go get washed and give me the shirt, I’1l put it in the wash. He takes off the bloody shirt and hands it to her.  18

dialogues.speaker: CARRIE
dialogues.text: Don’t forget your shoes. As Carrie goes off to wash his shirt, Russell bends down to remove his bloodied shoes. He sets a gun down.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Endless, boring trees, whiz by.

dialogues.speaker: CARRIE
dialogues.text: Can we stop, Frank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank pulls the car to the side of the highway. The women get out to smoke. The car doors shutting wakes Russell.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: Where are we?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Outside Lewisburg.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: I got some things to do in Lewisburg. Wake me up when we get there. Russell closes his eyes to nap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A succession of guys in suits and ties sit in chairs in the rear of Russell's fabric shop quietly waiting their turn. They do not speak or acknowledge each other as two female clerks hustle around checking bolts of fabric for curtains and drapes.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: He had a piece of everything, but mostly he ran his business out of Penn Drape and Curtains. Who knew what it all was? I’m sure the man had partners. They always have partners. Nobody keeps all the money, but everybody listened to Russ. And when you did something for Russ, you did it yourself. Like he said -  19

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: I don’t need two roads coming back to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur Grasso’s barber shop. Four barbers, two bootblacks, a manicurist, and three customers, one of them with his head back, eyes closed, getting a shave. The man’s bodyguard leafs through a magazine as he waits, then sets it down, gets up, and - We follow him out to the adjacent lobby of the hotel where he walks past shops, presumably to buy something at the kiosk up ahead, passing two other men coming the other way without acknowledging them - And we go back with these two as they walk past the same shops to the barber shop. They go in, but we keep going to the florist next door, settling on flower arrangements as ten shots ring out in the barber shop -

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: When Anastasia got killed in the barber shop, it was Russell who calmed things down so they weren't killing each other before it could all get straightened out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fingers raise the volume on the car radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell, in shirtsleeves, calmly talking to the men inside the car. We hear nothing over the loud car radio music.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Still, you’d never know it by looking at him. But all the roads led back to Russ. EXT. BUFALINO’S HOUSE - PITTSTON - DAY - 1957 The same modest house the Bufalinos will still be in twenty years from now.  20 EXT. SKINNY RAZOR’S HOUSE - PHILLY - DAY - 1957 Frank sits in an idling car, the tailpipe breathing steam into the chilly air.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: I was helping out Skinny and his friends with collections. Skinny comes down the steps of his house in a robe and slippers.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: That’s all Skinny did. Grill steaks and collect money. Skinny pokes his head in the passenger window. Doesn’t see what he expects to see.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: Where’s the money?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: He didn’t have it. He (said) -

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: Don’t tell me, let me guess. His mother died and the funeral set him back.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: His fuckin mother’s been dying over and over for ten years. Don’t leave. Skinny scampers back into the house and reemerges a moment later with a paper bag in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: Don’t use it. Just show it to him. Skinny sets the bag on the passenger seat and trots back to his house. Frank sees a gun in the bag and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. FRANK'S CAR
dialogues.text: Frank in his parked car, watching a street corner. Sees DEADBEAT #1 come around it.  21 We stay in the car to watch Frank approach the guy on the sidewalk, showing that he is holding a gun in the paper bag.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: In those days, you took along a gun just to show a guy. Today, they shoot you with it. The guy is terrified by the mere sight of the gun in the open bag. They both get into the car.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: In those days, you wanted your money tomorrow. These days, they want it yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skinny regards the guy standing before him.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: Tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: DEADBEAT
dialogues.text: Tomorrow. I swear.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: Here.

dialogues.speaker: DEADBEAT
dialogues.text: Here. Tomorrow. Skinny nods, Okay, go. But the guy doesn’t go.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: What.

dialogues.speaker: DEADBEAT
dialogues.text: How am I going to get home?

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: Take a fuckin bus, get out of here. The deadbeat leaves.  22 INT. FRANK & MARY’S HOUSE - EVENING - 1958 Frank comes in to find Mary cooking and his daughter Peggy sulking.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What's the matter with her?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Nothing. She knocked over something in the grocery store and made a mess. The grocer yelled at her and shoved her out.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: He pushed her? Frank turns to Peggy.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: He pushed you? Peggy nods.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: The grocery on the corner? Peggy nods.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (to Peggy, sweetly) Come with me sweetheart. Show me.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Frank, it was an accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank leads Peggy to the corner store where the burly GROCER is alone.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: That him? Peggy nods.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You go home, sweetheart. Tell your mother I'll be right there. Okay? Okay? He kisses her on the top of her head and sends her home. He then turns toward the grocery store.  23

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GROCER is alone whacking away at a leg of lamb with a meat cleaver as Frank enters.

dialogues.speaker: GROCER
dialogues.text: Frank, I'm sorry, but your kid was out of line. I only did what you and your wife should have done at home. Frank pulls the Grocer clear over the counter and slams him on the floor. Frank then takes aim for a second and stomps on the guy’s hand with all his weight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy has not gone home and is peeking into the store where she sees her father stomping up and down on the screaming Grocer’s hand. Terrified, Peggy turns and runs home as her father stomps on the Grocer writhing on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family eats in silence. Peggy steals glances at her father, afraid of him now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and Mary's daughter, DOLORES, is being baptized. Unlike the last time, there are a lot of attendees - mobsters from Downtown including Russell, Carrie, Bill Bufalino, his wife, Johnny the trucker, Skinny Razor and other assorted blue collar truckers and part time hoods. Peggy watches her father, all she sees is the image of her father’s heel crushing a hand.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: It was a beautiful occasion. Everybody showed up.(more to come)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank sits at a table with a cup of coffee when Whispers DiTullio sits down. Frank nods.  24

dialogues.speaker: WHISPERS
dialogues.text: You wanna pick up a quick ten grand? Whispers is true to his name speaking so softly Frank has to lean over to hear.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: This is not the Whispers they blew up in that car around the same time... FLASHCUT to a car blowing up. Then back to the diner - Whispers continuing to fill Frank in on the job.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: This is the other Whispers. The good one who knew how to make money.

dialogues.speaker: WHISPERS
dialogues.text: It's a great business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big industrial laundry service, but with a lot of idle machines.

dialogues.speaker: WHISPERS, (OVERLAP)
dialogues.text: We supply all the bed sheets, towels, and linen to most of the Atlantic City casinos and hotels. We pick it up, wash it, iron it, and deliver it. Until recently, it’s been a license to print money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This place looks a lot like the other place, only busy.

dialogues.speaker: WHISPERS, (OVERLAP)
dialogues.text: Except there’s this fuckin’ laundry down in Delaware that’s knocking us dead. They’re cutting the price. They’re scaring our drivers. They’re sucking up more and more of our business. I’ma little concerned.  25

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank leans in closer as Whisper talks.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Whenever anybody says they’re a little concerned, they are very concerned. When they say they’re more than a little concerned, they’re desperate.

dialogues.speaker: WHISPERS
dialogues.text: I’m more than a little concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As workers haul laundry out to trucks with the name Cadillac Linen Service painted on them -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whispers passes an envelope across the table.

dialogues.speaker: WHISPERS
dialogues.text: We’ve gotta put these fuckin guys out of business somehow.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yeah. Frank takes a quick look inside the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: This isn’t ten grand.

dialogues.speaker: WHISPERS
dialogues.text: I know. Don’t worry. You know I’m good for it. I didn’t wanna go on the street asking for that kind of money and have anybody asking questions. Frank looks at him, not sure he can trust him to pay up.

dialogues.speaker: WHISPERS
dialogues.text: What’s the matter, Frank? Take it. What am I gonna do stiff you for the money. You think I’m nuts? I’m looking to put these Delaware bastards out of business and we'll all be good.  26 Frank finally puts the envelope in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: WHISPERS
dialogues.text: And remember, please! This is between us. Don’t mention nothing to nobody, even Skinny. That’s why I didn’t wanna borrow the ten grand off the street. INT. FRANK & MARY’S HOUSE - NIGHT - 1958 Frank takes five hundred from the $2000 stack of bills in the envelope and gives the rest to Mary, at the kitchen table with their three girls.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I hit on a ten-dollar daily double. She knows it isn’t true, but doesn’t care. Peggy knows it isn’t true and does care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank drives slowly past the front of the Cadillac Linen Service building. Then around the side. Then around the back. He notes a burglar alarm box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits in his parked car, having a look at the building at night. He gets out and crosses past the trucks, peers in one of the industrial windows at the washing and pressing machines inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At his car, Frank takes out a red 5-gallon gasoline tank. He unscrews his car’s gas cap and shoves a two foot length of rubber hose into the tank. He sucks on the hose for a few seconds and quickly spits out the taste of gasoline before he shoves the hose into the red gasoline tank. He puts the red tank in the trunk of his car where there are two more red tanks and a box of dynamite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts on a dark jacket over his dark clothes and heads for the door.  27

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he comes out and walks toward his car, he sees Skinny standing next to his own, and stops.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: Angelo wants to see you. Frank jumps in Skinny’s car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skinny leads Frank into the restaurant. Empty except for Angelo, Russell and Phil the bartender. Phil closes the door as they walk in. The door snaps as he locks it. He puts the closed sign up.

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO
dialogues.text: Sit down, Frank. Frank sits. Listens to a silence before -

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’re you doing in Delaware? Frank glances from Angelo Bruno - who’s studying him - to Russell Bufalino - who isn’t - and wisely decides to tell the truth.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Bombing out a laundry service.

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO
dialogues.text: For who? (nothing from Frank) This is not one of those times to not say.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: For Whispers. The other Whispers.

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO
dialogues.text: You know who owns the Cadillac Linen Service?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Some Jews in the laundry business.

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO
dialogues.text: They own part of it. Somebody else has an interest in that. You know who?  28

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Who.

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO
dialogues.text: No. I do. I own the other part. Not I know who owns the other part.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I didn’t know that.

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO
dialogues.text: Whispers didn’t tell you it was the Jew mob?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: He said Jew washerwomen.

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO
dialogues.text: Jew washerwomen. What else he say? I'll bet he said keep it to yourself. Don’t say nothin’ to nobody Downtown. Frank nods. Listens to the amplified sounds. Then -

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I didn't check. I’m sorry, I should've checked. You want me to give him his money back?

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO
dialogues.text: He won’t need it. You can keep it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO
dialogues.text: He won’t need it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO
dialogues.text: Thank Russell. I wouldn’t have wasted my time. I’d have let the Jews have you.  29

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (to Russell) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whispers waits on the street.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (IN SYNC)
dialogues.text: It’s best to use something brand new. Right out of the box. Otherwise, you don’t know where it’s been. What somebody did with it you don’t even know about. Whispers sees Frank come around the corner and walk toward him - a friend walking toward a friend - as if to give him a tip on a race or football game.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (IN SYNC)
dialogues.text: So I recommend something new right out of the box. Frank shoots him with a .32 and keeps walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank is seated at a small table before a soundless television set.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Naturally, the next thing you want to do is throw it away. (ALT: ...get rid of it.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank drives slowly across the empty bridge, slows down and scales the gun into the river as effortlessly as a frisbee.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (IN SYNC)
dialogues.text: There’s a spot in the Schuylkill River everybody uses. They ever send divers down there, they’d be able to arm a small country.  30 INT. FRANK & MARY’S HOUSE - MORNING - 1958 Frank sits at the kitchen table reading a newspaper. Glances up at his daughter Peggy, then back down at the paper with a WeeGee-like photo of a body on the sidewalk surrounded by cops and passersby. Next to it is a full face mugshot of Whispers.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (IN SYNC)
dialogues.text: With Whispers, it broke the ice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank pulls up, gets out, throws a gun in the river.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (IN SYNC)
dialogues.text: It was like the army.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank throws another gun in the river.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (IN SYNC)
dialogues.text: You followed orders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another gun hits the water, and this time we go underwater with it as it sinks to the bottom, where there’s an arsenal of discarded guns.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: And when I handled things for Russell it was never for money, but as a show of respect. You ran a little errand, you did a favor, you got a little favor back if you ever needed it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Frank approaches Russell’s table, the two sitting with Russell leap to their feet, nod at Frank and move away.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: And you always hurried back. IRENE, the waitress, smiles and affectionately touches Frank's shoulder as she clears the dishes.  31

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank walks down a rain-slicked Downtown street with the Villa di Roma waitress - Irene - stepping on reflections of lights and neon signs on the wet pavement.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: No time is a good time to leave your wife, but that’s when I left mine. They disappear into a cheap hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank pulls the Lincoln into the lot of a roadside motel set down next to the highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While their wives smoke outside, Frank and Russell check in. Only instead of taking money from either of them, the manager gives Russell an envelope of cash.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Russell and Frank drive along a street in Lewisburg.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: Here it is. Frank pulls to the curb in front of a fur shop. Gets out, leaving the motor running, goes inside. Comes back out a moment later with an envelope of cash which he gives to Russell who puts it in the glove compartment, shuts it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell waits in the Lincoln, Frank comes out of the jewelry store with another envelope. Russell adds it to the others in the glove compartment and turns to give his wife and Irene two small gold brooches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell and his wife Carrie, along with Frank and his second wife, Irene, and his two older daughters, Peggy and Maryanne - bowl.  32 Peggy - about 10 now - and even more uncomfortable with him - keeps her distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and Russell drink beers and watch the women and children bowl.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: I think that kid’s a-scared of me.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: She’s a-scared of me, too. She’s one of those sensitive kids. You know.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: That’s not good, Frank. She shouldn’t be a-scared of you. You gotta be close with your daughters, you know. You gotta be close with your family. You’re blessed to have them. I told you Carrie and I, you know, we can’t have kids, you know. So you're blessed. Bufalino motions Peggy to join him and her father.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: Sweetheart, do you know why God made the sky so high?

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: Because he didn’t want the birds to bang their heads. Peggy is expressionless.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: (still trying) You want candy or something to eat?

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: No. Peggy goes back to bowling and starts laughing with Maryanne.  33

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: Maybe it’s okay that she’s a- scared of me, but she shouldn’t be a-scared of you. You’re her father. You’ve got to keep an eye on that.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You’re right.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: It happens sometimes in a divorce. The kids get nervous. They start resenting you.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I’m lucky the way Mary and Renie get along. The kids move back and forth with no problems.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: It can make all the difference, when the parents ain’t at war. Russell looks over and smiles and waves to Peggy, but she looks away.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: You good with the union?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You kidding? Best union in the world.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: Well, a good friend of ours is gonna need some help.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yeah? Who?

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: I mean the top guy. He’s gonna need some help.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You mean Hoffa?

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: He’s got people who are looking to make trouble. Some bastards tried to pipe him over a workman's comp case.  34

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I heard he beat the shit out of them.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: Yeah, but he’s still gonna need somebody he can trust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thunderstorm throws rain down on Frank he hurries from his car to the Villa di Roma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell and Skinny Razor are lingering at one end of the bar. Frank is sitting on his own at a table having a glass of wine. Russell is checking his watch. The bar phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: Right on time. Skinny answers the phone.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: (into the phone) Skinny. (listening) How you doing? Good. And the family? Yeah, we’re all good. Knock wood. Oh yeah, Angelo’s fine. He got a good physical with the doctor last week. He’s in the pink. Knock wood again. Let me give McGee the phone. You take care of yourself, you hear. Skinny hands the phone to Russell. But Russell doesn’t talk into it he walks the phone over to Frank’s table and sits down. He puts an envelope on the table.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: (into the phone) I got that friend I told you about. He’s sitting here with me. He’s a good union man. I want him to meet his president. See what you think of him. Russell hands Frank the phone.  35

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: Say hello.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (into the phone) Hello?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Hi Frank. It’s Jimmy Hoffa. The image of Frank and Russell at the table slows down.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Nowadays, young people don’t know who Jimmy Hoffa was. Maybe they know he disappeared, that’s about it. But back then, there wasn’t an American alive who didn’t know who he was. INT. TEAMSTER’S WXDC HEADQUARTERS - OFFICE - CONTINUOUS Hoffa is behind a large desk wearing a low-cost black suit with a white shirt and black tie.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Hiya, Frank. This is Jimmy Hoffa. Glad to meet you, even over the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy comes through a large crowd of workers eager to shake his hand.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: In the 50’s, he was as famous as Elvis. In the 60’s, he was as famous as the Beatles. Next to the President he was the most powerful man in the country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy orating before the crowd of workers - televised.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: If you got it, a truck brought it to you. Food, clothing, medicine, fuel for homes and industry. The day our trucks stop America stops.  36

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THE VILLA DI ROMA
dialogues.text: as the slow-motion image of Frank on the phone and Russell at the table returns to normal -

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: I heard you paint houses.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I do my own carpentry too.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: That’s what I wanted to hear. I understand you’re a brother of mine.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Local 107. Since 1947.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Our friend speaks very highly of you.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: He’s not an easy man to please.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I do my best.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THE TEAMSTER RALLY
dialogues.text: Hoffa speaking to the workers -

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: We are facing a struggle as never before. The most important thing the labor movement cannot do without is solidarity. Big business has been on the attack -

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THE VILLA DI ROMA
dialogues.text: Frank still on the phone with Hoffa -

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: - they want to tear the union apart. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Big business is working with the government to sow the seeds of dissent at a time when we need unity. We need solidarity more than ever in our history. Not just our history but the history of the working man in America.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: You want to be a part of this fight?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yes I do.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: You want to be a part of this history?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yes I do.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Can you be in Chicago tomorrow? Russell pushes the envelope on the table toward Frank.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: For a minute there, I thought it was Patton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cars pull into a parking lot behind a building.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA V/O
dialogues.text: Go to Chicago. Speak to Joey Glimco at Local 777. You'll be working in Public Relations. Frank and Joey Glimco climb out of one of the cars. They, and several other men enter the back door of the building -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank is seated with JOEY GLIMCO, head of the Chicago taxicab drivers union.  38 They are seated on a white tile counter draped in towels. Glimco is smoking a fat cigar in the steam-filled room.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: You’re only here because Jimmy’s getting screwed. It’s the Seafarers Union trying to sign up the same non-union cab drivers we are. Lesbians, a lot of them, for some reason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman cab driver walks into a diner.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY, (OVERLAP)
dialogues.text: This is what we have to deal with, how to get these drivers to join us rather than Paul Hall’s union. He’s bullshitting people that he can get a better contract than Jimmy. Frank walks over to the woman’s cab, opens the door and hot-wires

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and cabs into it.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY, (OVERLAP)
dialogues.text: You understand, you’re here because nobody knows you or what the fuck you're doing.

dialogues.speaker: MICHIGAN
dialogues.text: the other Local 777 guys push stolen non-union Lake Michigan while cops stand around watching.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY, (OVERLAP)
dialogues.text: Jimmy has Daley’s cops’ okay on this. They won’t help us push but they’1l make sure nobody stops us.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: This is a lot of work.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Have you thought about using candy? Joey just looks at him, not sure what he’s saying.  39

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trunk of a car opens revealing boxes of dynamite. Joey and Frank carry the boxes to a back door of a cab garage, held open by another man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is silent. Full of taxi cabs. Suddenly they start exploding -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and Joey Glimco approach a fruit stand.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: One thing about Jimmy, never make him wait. You have a meeting with him, get there on time. Get there early. I can’t stress this enough. He goes by time. Joey taps at some watermelons.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: We should get going then.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: The other thing about him is he doesn’t drink. Imagine that? He’s the head of all the truck drivers in the world and don’t drink. He won’t even let you drink around him. He calls it idiot juice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Joey carefully cuts a hole in a watermelon, Frank checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: The other thing about him - he doesn’t like watermelon. Joey pours a fifth of rum into the hole in the watermelon  40

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sip from bottles of ginger ale - Joey, Frank and Jimmy Hoffa - but only two of them are eating the sliced- up spiked watermelon.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (excited) You shoulda seen them sink right in the water. One after the other. I’‘1l bet this morning, when they went looking for their cabs, they didn’t know what hit them.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Sinking the cabs. Great idea Joey.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: It wasn’t my idea. It was Frank. Hoffa looks at Frank, impressed.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It's not complicated. You just push.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: He just took over the pier. They did exactly what he said. (gobbles up watermelon slice) I never seen a guy walk through a crowd like he does and he doesn’t touch a single person! I’m not kidding. I swear. Guys who didn’t even know him, never saw him before in their lives, still got out of his way. I’m telling you it was like “the parting of the waves” - like Moses! Hoffa looks over at a clearly mortified Frank listening to Glimco’s excessive praise.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: (to Joey) You need him to stay another couple of days?

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Yeah. We still got some dribs and drabs. Glimco hands Frank a slice of rum-laced watermelon.  4l

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: (curious) You two sure like watermelon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey has left. It’s just Jimmy and Frank now. Jimmy in pajamas and slippers. (Frank, still fully clothed, stands near a utility rolling cot.)

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Everybody has to be united in the same direction, or there’s not progress for the worker, Frank. You saw it firsthand. To me those guys ain’t union. They’re like Nazi collaborators. Operating behind our lines. You were in the war. You know what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Good! Jimmy gets up in his pajamas and goes into his bedroom leaving the door open. Frank arranges the pillows on the cot. He looks into the bedroom and sees that Hoffa is already sound asleep. Frank stretches out on the cot but he’s fully awake.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Back in the 1950's, Jimmy was already the president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. The most powerful union man in the country. Still, he didn’t make me stay in his suite in Chicago because he liked me. He made me stay with him because he didn’t want me registering in my name at the hotel. By staying with him in the big suite, there was no proof I was even in Chicago. It’s all about secrets. Just like Whispers, except for Whispers it didn’t turn out so good.  42

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MINIATURE GOLF COURSE
dialogues.text: Jimmy and his wife Josephine, and Frank and Irene and his still-growing family including infant Connie in a stroller - play miniature golf. Jimmy dotes on Peggy, helps her with the club.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: After Chicago, Jimmy and I got close. Our wives hit it off and with Jimmy and Josephine’s kids mostly grown up, they got a kick out of our kids, especially Peggy. She and Jimmy fell for each other right away. Jo wants a snapshot of Jimmy and Peggy together. As they pose for the picture -

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Can you keep a secret?

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: You know what I like even better than getting my picture took?

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy sets a tray of ice cream sundaes on the table, placing the first one in front of Peggy.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: To Peg, Jimmy wasn’t like Russ, or Skinny or even me. For one thing, Jimmy didn’t have a nickname like the “Razor” or “The Hunchback”. Also, to her, he was helping people make more money, live better lives. He wasn’t stomping on somebody’s hand. Jimmy really does love ice cream, dipping his spoon into his sundae and savoring its taste like fine wine.  43

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy stands in front of a blackboard reading an essay from a piece of paper. A banner above the blackboard reads: “CAREER DAY”.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: “If you have it, a truck brought it to you.” This is what Mr. Hoffa says, and it’s true. He’s the president of the Teamsters Union with over a million members. They all support him because they now have steady jobs, great pay and a pension for when they retire. Frank sits in a chair off to the side at the head of the class. It’s his turn at career day. Peggy and Frank are both wearing gold and blue enamel “A Friend of Jimmy Hoffa” buttons written across a miniature trailer truck.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: The Teamster Pension Fund had eight billion dollars in it and Jimmy had complete authority over every bit of it. INT. HOFFA’S OFFICE - TEAMSTERS’ WXDC HQ - DAY - 1959 Hoffa behind a large desk in a huge office with drapes and a window view of the White House. JAKE GOTTLIEB, a builder, is showing Hoffa a two-foot high architect’s model of “The Dunes”, the Las Vegas casino he is proposing expanding.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE GOTTLIEB
dialogues.text: A bridge loan is all I’m asking.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Bill Bufalino standing behind Gottlieb. Frank is standing behind Bill.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: I’m not pissing away my members’ pension dough on bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE GOTTLIEB
dialogues.text: You won’t. You can’t. I’ve got Minksy’s follies. I’ve got the first topless act on the Strip. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: JAKE GOTTLIEB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m just asking for a golf course. Jimmy you know you’ve never lost a dime with me.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: We would appreciate anything you can do to help Jake along on this.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE GOTTLIEB
dialogues.text: One five is all I need for the completion bond.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Whatever you can do Jimmy. Hoffa waves at Bill.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: (to Bill) Okay. Okay. Go to the bank. Gottlieb remains seated beaming as Bill and Frank leave the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and Bill open a large ebony credenza with an elaborate Chinese design. Bill opens the credenza to reveal stacks of cash in neat bank banded units reading: $10,000, $50,000, etc. Bill rummages around the stacks until he piles twelve stacks marked $100,000 into Frank’s arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Peggy still up at the front of the class -

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: And, because of Mr. Hoffa, workers have medical insurance for when they get sick and know that when they retire they’re not going to go hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sign reads: “ALLEN DORFMAN INSURANCE.” Allen Dorfman is seated wearing a “Friend of Hoffa” pin in his lapel.  45

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: There was so much paperwork back then that Jimmy had to use an insurance company, run by his friend, “Red” Dorfman’s son, Allen, to process the loans. A title appears: Allen Dorfman, shot eight times in the head in a Chicago parking lot, 1979.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell in the curtain shop checking bolts of cloth talking with his cousin, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Russ and his friends used to get guys like Gottlieb million-dollar loans and then tack on a ten- percent finder’s fee.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: I appreciate what he did. He’s okay. You make sure you thank Marteduzzo from me.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: He'd be glad to hear that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cranes building the casinos such as the Stardust, the Dunes, the Sands etc. in BG.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Back then, because the money was for gambling, a lot of snooty banks wouldn’t lend casinos money for construction. I’m serious. But without the regular banks, it was the Teamsters’ billion-dollar pension fund that stepped in and lent the money that built Las Vegas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several women sitting under hair dryers. One of the women is Jimmy's wife, Josephine.  46

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: There was more business than anybody could handle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: * POSTCARD: photo of a large real estate display with a golf course. * POSTCARD: photo of a fleet of charter fishing boats. * POSTCARD: photo of Aspen Lodge and ski slopes.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Jimmy had to shove some of the deals off on to Josephine who had no idea she had twenty-two percent of a Florida land deal called “Sun Valley”, some charter fishing boats, and a ski lodge with its own mountain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some parked cars. In the backseat of one sits a man wearing sunglasses and a fedora - SAM “MOMO” GIANCANA.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (IN SYNC)
dialogues.text: One of Jimmy’s clients was Sam “Momo” Giancana, who was friends with the Kennedys from back when Jack’s father made his fortune (alongside the Italians) as a bootlegger during Prohibition. The old timers worked with him. Momo - Sinatra - they all partied with the Kennedys. Momo and Kennedy even had the same girlfriend. Together. At the same time. EXT. GRAVEYARD —- CHICAGO - DAY Some mob guys walk across the lawns of a graveyard, jotting down the names on the tombstones.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (IN SYNC)
dialogues.text: So it was easy for the Mob to help Joe Kennedy get his son elected president by making sure he won in Illinois.  47

dialogues.speaker: INT. POLLING PLACE
dialogues.text: The men from the graveyard sign the names from the tombstones on voting registers, then get back in line to do it again.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (IN SYNC)
dialogues.text: In exchange, the new president was going to get Castro out of Cuba so our guys could get their casinos and race tracks and shrimp boats in Havana back.

dialogues.speaker: TV NEWS IMAGES
dialogues.text: Kennedy vs Nixon. Election night shows tight race. The next day, Nixon’s press secretary reads the concession letter to Kennedy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chicago boss, SAM “MOMO” GIANCANA, and New Jersey boss, TONY “TONY PRO” PROVENZANO, are watching the Kennedy election victory on television. Momo, Tony Pro, and the roomful of hoods cheer and toast each other with the Kennedy victory.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: The Italians wanted Kennedy the Irishman as President... and they got him. On TV, Jack Kennedy goes up to stage to make his victory speech. INT. HOFFA’S LAKE ORION HOUSE - DETROIT - DAY - 1960 Jimmy, Jo, and their kids James P., Barbara and adopted son Chuckie - all in their late teens - watching Kennedy and his family on TV - Jackie, Joe, Bobby, Ted - milling around a stage in Hyannis Port for his victory speech.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Jeezuschrist! God damn Kennedys.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Jimmy, please, the kids.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Why? They’re gonna have to learn. We’re going to war. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I told you, you can’t trust a millionaire’s kids. As Jack makes his speech, a camera finds Robert Kennedy.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Especially that miserable little sonofabitch. ... and all the bullshit problems he’s already put me through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby Kennedy regards Hoffa like he’s an insect. It’s ten minutes into the hearing now -

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Are you saying you don’t remember doing any favors for Johnny Dio or you don’t remember the conversation?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: I’m saying, to the best of my recollection, I must recall on my memory, I cannot remember.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Where did this twenty thousand dollars come from?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: From individuals.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Which individuals?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Offhand, that particular amount of money I borrowed I don’t know at this particular moment, but the record of my loans, which I requested, I have, and out of all the moneys I loaned over this period of time I went into these ventures. Everyone looks at each other to see if that made any sense to them.  49

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell enters and distributes JFK election materials to some regulars. A “Kennedy For President” poster hangs on the restaurant’s mirror.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Even Russ did his part getting Kennedy elected, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christmas Eve. Lights glow on a tree. Music on the hifi. The Bufalinos, and Frank and Irene and the girls sit around the Christmas tree, opening the gifts Russell has given them - jewelry for Irene, clothes and toys for the girls.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: For guys like Russ, it couldn’t have been better.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: (hating to have to say it) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (IN SYNC)
dialogues.text: So what’s the first thing Jack Kennedy does to repay Chicago for all their help?

dialogues.speaker: TV IMAGE
dialogues.text: Of John F. Kennedy being sworn in at his inauguration.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (IN SYNC)
dialogues.text: He puts his crazy brother in charge of the Justice Department. And what’s the first thing Bobby does? He goes after not just Jimmy - which in a way you could understand - Jimmy hated the Kennedys so much he gave Nixon a half a million in Teamster cash. They were the only union to back Nixon - but Bobby also goes after Giancana and all the other guys who put his brother in the White House.  50 EXT. FRANK’S HOUSE - MORNING - MARCH 1961 Frank stands on the front lawn in his robe and slippers, watching a repairman on a telephone pole down the street working on the lines, phone company van parked below.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Everybody was sure everybody's phone was bugged. I mean you couldn’t say any names on the phone. Everybody was “your friend” or “our friend,” whether they were your friend or not. Even when you talked about Bobby Kennedy. He was “our friend”.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA looks down from above as upon a chessboard where Hoffa, Bill Bufalino and Frank inch their way across the courthouse’s polished marble floor surrounded by a small army of reporters, cameramen, and TV anchors waving microphones. The press keep shouting questions at Hoffa and his trio until they are finally rescued by burly Court Officers who shove the press aside and drag Hoffa, Frank and Bill through a courtroom door.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: It really got much worse when Bobby became Attorney General. When he ran the McClellan Committee he held lots of bullshit hearings, but he couldn’t put anybody in jail. Now, he was the Attorney General and he could send anybody to jail, and, no question Jimmy was at the top of Bobby’s hit list. He even set up a special “Get Hoffa Squad” where he had his own guys from the FBI and IRS working around the clock. Their only job was trying to put Jimmy Hoffa in jail. I’m serious. That’s all they did. INT. HOFFA’S OFFICE - TEAMSTERS’ WXDC HQ - DAY - 1961 An agitated Jimmy listening on a phone behind his desk stares angrily at six large, tough, teamster officials, including Frank.  51

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: (slams phone) I’m working with a room full of fuckin’ idiots. You pricks! You motherfuckers put Johnny O’Rourke’s kid on as a “general organizer” for thirty-six grand at the same time you let him sell insurance to his father’s locals. Don’t you know I’m under the gun? I’ve got that Kennedy cocksucker sticking his nose up my ass and you let this shit happen in public. You dumb motherfuckers trying to put me away? Frank turns and leaves the office.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Tell me now so I can kill you worthless fucks right here.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: I could see it was getting to him. He was acting crazy. He was not the same Jimmy. He was vicious. It was really hard just being around him. Hoffa sees Frank leave. Stops. INT. HOFFA’S OFFICE - FOYER - CONTINUOUS Jimmy catches up with Frank.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Where you going?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I quit. You ain’t calling me a motherfucker!

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: What’s the matter with you! That don’t apply to you.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Then let me know that. They wanna take what you’re saying-- they can take it. Not me.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: But I said it don’t apply to you.  52

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You got a problem pull me aside. Don’t insult me and then say it don’t apply to me.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: (walks Frank back toward office) Okay. Okay. Come on. You know me better that.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: In the end, I had to stick by him. I knew the bullshit he was going through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and Russell alone at a table, floating three coffee beans in their after-dinner Sambuca shots.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Russ, I don’t know how Jimmy's running the union with Bobby and the FBI up his ass all the time. He’s going crazy.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: Tell Jimmy I’m sorry for his troubles, but if worse comes to worst, the old timers know the father. They talk... and they could straighten things out.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: But he can’t understand why you guys helped the Kennedy pricks get elected in the first place. It don’t make sense to him.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: Jimmy don’t have to know everything. You understand? Sometimes it’s better.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: He’s too emotional. He gets caught up in bullshit like some guy being late. Who gives a shit? He misses the big picture. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (whispers) Like Cuba. Like getting us back in Havana. Like getting us back the casinos. Like getting rid of that Castro sonofabitch.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Jeezus!

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: They had a word with the old man. And he had a word with his son, and he let Jack know, you know, who he fuckin owes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank pulls into a South Philly trucking company lot, climbs out of his car and speaks to a guy.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO, (OVERLAP)
dialogues.text: So, I want you to go see Phil at Milestone Hauling. He’s gonna have a rig for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank behind the wheel of a Milestone semi.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO, (OVERLAP)
dialogues.text: You take it, and you drive it down to Baltimore to this concrete plant on Eastern Avenue. You can’t miss it, it’s the only one there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank pulls the rig onto the grounds of the plant. There’s a little landing strip next to it.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO, (OVERLAP)
dialogues.text: A guy will meet you there. A fairy named Ferrie. Dave Ferrie, whose alopecia has him wearing a homemade reddish wig, drawn eyebrows and makeup, directs Frank to back his rig up to where some army trucks are parked.  54

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO, (OVERLAP)
dialogues.text: You’1l pick up some things and he’ll give you some paperwork for the load in case you get stopped. Frank watches some Maryland National Guardsmen transfer weapons, ammo, and uniforms from their trucks to his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank drives the rig down Route 13.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO, (OVERLAP)
dialogues.text: Drive the truck down to Florida. That's where you'll leave it. A dog track outside Jacksonville.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A deserted greyhound race track. Stuffed rabbit on a rail pole. Frank pulls the truck into the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO, (OVERLAP)
dialogues.text: A guy with big ears named Hunt will meet you there and give you a car to get you back to Philly. As the guy gives Frank the keys to a car, Frank regards his ears. They don’t look so big.

dialogues.speaker: BIG EARS
dialogues.text: What are you looking at? You looking at my ears?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I ain’t looking at your ears.

dialogues.speaker: BIG EARS
dialogues.text: I had an operation, so there’s no need for anyone looking at my ears anymore.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I ain’t looking at your ears. Big Ears walks away. Frank climbs into the car and watches as a bunch of Cubans begin unloading the weapons and ammo from the truck he just drove down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 55 A glum Frank and Russell sitting at the bar watching TV showing news footage of the Bay of Pigs disaster.

dialogues.speaker: TV ANCHOR
dialogues.text: A counter-revolutionary coup led by Cuban exiles and backed by the Central Intelligence Agency, failed to unseat the island’s Communist dictator, Fidel Castro...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: It was a disaster. Kennedy was supposed to send in planes for cover but he pulled back and a lot of Cuban guys got killed on the beach. Castro fulminates making an anti-American speech on TV. INT. HOFFA’S OFFICE - TEAMSTERS’ WXDC HQ - DAY APRIL 1961 A furious Hoffa in his office with Bill Bufalino. is going through a stack of subpoenas.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Just like I predicted. Right after they fuck up Cuba, Boobie starts coming after me and the union. He’s looking for some cheap publicity. That’s what he’s doing.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: It'll blow over, Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: (annoyed) What’s the matter with you? It’1l never blow over. You think they’re ever gonna forget the money I gave Nixon? Never! Hoffa sweeps the subpoenas off his desk.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Jimmy, please, calm down. Some of the old timers are trying to reach the old man Kennedy now. He’s supposed to be sick, but... Hoffa  56

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: (interrupts) Are you nuts? The old man ain’t “sick”. He just had a stroke. He’s useless. He turned into an eggplant.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Oh shit! You can’t blame anybody for that.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: I can! I blame his kids. The two of them. They did it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSEPH P. KENNEDY, 80, in pajamas and wrapped in a robe, is seated in a wheelchair with a male NURSE watching a variety show.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA, (OVERLAP)
dialogues.text: - They gave their own father the stroke. I know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank slips a .38 in the back of his waistband as Peggy watches unnoticed. He puts on a car coat. A TV plays a news report on Castro.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Everybody started thinking the same thing: Maybe Jimmy was right about the Kennedys in the first place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s late. The house is dark. As he’s leaving with his suitcase -

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: To work. Go to bed.  57

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. FRANK'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: Frank closes the trunk, gets in his car, sets the .38 on the passenger seat. Peggy watches from a window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun-bleached coastline of Miami Beach. Everyone in short-sleeves and sunglasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank climbs out of his car. A bellman helps him with his luggage. Everyone else arriving for the annual Teamsters Convention looks just as much like a gangster as he does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy and Frank share the suite. Jimmy knots a tie. Frank sticks a pistol in his back waistband and slips a sports jacket on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank stands next to check-in tables outside a ballroom, scrutinizing the faces of those showing their union cards to clerks for admittance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While Jimmy addresses the convention delegates, Frank surveys them, looking at their hands for cameras or guns.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: We’re gonna get through all this legal bullshit garbage. Little “Boobie” Kennedy can’t do a thing to us because we’re the biggest, best and most honest union in the country. Crowd cheers.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Plus we have the strongest and most loyal members... Audience cheers.  58

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: --. the greatest shop stewards and headbreakers -- ah, I mean Education Committee... Audience laughs.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: +--+. and with Frank Fitzsimmons, my Executive Vice President, having my back... (points to Fitz on dais) Right Fitz? FRANK FITZSIMMONS, 53, a bloated man raises his large scotch on the rocks to the cheering crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy and Frank in pajamas, getting ready to turn in.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You gave Fitz a nice “hello” tonight. I hope he deserves it.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Why? Wadda ya mean? What’s wrong with Fitz?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Nothing, Jimmy. I don’t mean it as a knock on the guy.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Yeah? Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Sure, the guy’s loyal. He’s evena nice guy, but he’s not too sharp. You know, he plays a lot of golf.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: But that’s who you want for a number two. A nice guy. Not dumb, but somebody you can have walking behind you without getting knifed.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Maybe you’re right, Jimmy. That makes sense.  59

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: I may have faults, but being wrong isn’t one of them. I can sleep like a babe with Fitz. It’s the Little Guy I have to worry about. A song with the lyrics “You’re my boy, Tony Pro, We’re all yours” begins as -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car pulls up to a one-story box of a building that looks like an abandoned bar. A short man in a black suit gets out with a couple of other men -

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: The Little Guy was Tony Provenzano. A capo in a big New Jersey crew and the president of Local 560 in Union City, New Jersey. The song continues over -—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Pro walks into the crowded place, his Teamster workingmen supporters cheer him, wave “Vote TONY ‘PRO’ and Slate” signs, bang on drink trays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pro, seated at a microphone, wearing glasses now, haltingly reads his prepared remarks to the men —

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: You turl - you work - while the corporation kings - and princes of industry - with their vast - expense accounts - and salary - and lugerous yachts - make vast donations - to politicians - yes - who have dedicated themselves - to our - destruction.

dialogues.speaker: TEAMSTERS
dialogues.text: Down with them! Down with them!  60

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Pro and Jimmy came up together and were close -

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: He’s out of control. He’s got a hand in everybody’s pocket. He’s shaking down the trucking companies right and left. He's threatening people. I mean, once in awhile, okay, but all the time? It's drawing attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car drives down a highway past farms.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: I didn't need Jimmy to warn me about Tony Pro.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: ANTHONY CASTELLITO fiddles with the radio in the front passenger seat, searching for a station in the static.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
