dialogues.text: What did I need to know? As Castellito settles on a station and sits back, SALLY BUGS, in the back seat, loops a nylon rope around Castellito’s neck and strangles him -

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: The man had Sally Bugs strangle Tony Castellito just because Castellito was coming up big in the union. Pro was so worried about the guy that after he had Sally Bugs strangle the guy, he had Sally stick him in a tree shredder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sally and the driver smoke outside the car as a tree shredder chews up something.  61

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: That way there’d be no competition, not even from the grave.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Guys like that give unions a bad name. Something’s got to be done.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Him being him, that could be tough.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: No. No. I don’t want that. I mean getting working guys who know the union, card-carrying teamsters like you and me, to start running to take over some of the locals.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: He’s not going to like that.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: So what? I’m the president. I run the union. All I need is some guys who know their way around and know how to handle themselves. That’s all. (Hoffa claps Frank’s shoulder) That’s why I want you to run for president of Local 326. Frank is stunned by Jimmy’s belief in him.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: You’re like family to me, Frank. You, Irene, the girls. Lovely Peggy. But that’s not why I’m doing this. I’m not giving you anything you didn’t earn.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I don’t know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Say you'll do it. That’s all you’ve got to say. (whispered joke) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Plus, I can guarantee you’re gonna win.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I’ll do it.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Good. Frank watches as Jimmy’s head hits the pillow and within seconds is asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank's Lincoln parked at the side of I-80 West, all the luggage out of the trunk. As Frank and Russell change a flat tire, the wives seize the opportunity for a cigarette on the guard rail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Teamster pin on a lapel. It’s on Frank’s lapel as he parks a 1962 Lincoln by the loading docks of a trucking company and climbs out, wearing a suit like Jimmy’s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Frank enters the trucking company OWNER takes one look at Frank’s suit and union pin and pulls an envelope from his desk to give him. Frank shakes his head no.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: That’s okay, I don’t need that. I just came over to introduce myself. Frank Sheeran. The new President of 326. The owner, surprised, puts the envelope back in the desk and tentatively shakes Frank’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: What can I say - Hoffa took me out of a meat truck and put me in the union. He gave me my start, gave me my first charter, gave me my first union.  63

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank in his own office now, behind a desk, talking with a truck driver dressed like he used to dress -

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: If they can prove you stole from them what they’re going to want is names. Would you give them names to keep from going to jail?

dialogues.speaker: TRUCK DRIVER
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Good. The lawyers will take care of this. You got nothing to worry about. The truck driver gets up to shake Frank’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the jury out of the room, attorney Bill Bufalino - the same Teamster attorney who represented Frank in his trucking theft case - appeals to Judge William Miller to have a case thrown out - this one against Hoffa.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Your Honor, Mr. Hoffa was advised by counsel that it was perfectly legal for his wife to be part owner of a trucking business. Still, when the McClellan Committee challenged its legality, she immediately withdrew from the company. Among the spectators, and there aren’t that many beyond some print journalists, is a young man in a raincoat.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: This should have been the end of the matter. There has been no indictment secured against my client in thirteen grand juries. The nut in the raincoat walks down the aisle toward the defense and prosecution tables -  64

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Your Honor, this is an example of a personal vendetta against my client and his family by a frustrated Justice Department and Attorney General, Robert Kennedy - The nut pushes open the gate, pulls out a gun, points it at Jimmy, who rushes him, grabs him. The gun - a pellet gun - goes off and everyone scrambles for cover as Jimmy wrestles the guy to the floor. Jimmy's adopted son/bodyguard, Chuckie O’Brien - who looks Italian because he is - jumps over the railing and beats the guy in the head until the marshals get there and take over. Jimmy is thrilled with Chuckie -

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: (raises Chuckie’s arm) This is my boy. I raised this kid. (calmly to crowd) Remember. Always charge a guy with a gun and run away from a guy with a knife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young would-be assassin, face bloody, stands for his mug shot, holding a booking placard that identifies him as Warren Swanson.

dialogues.speaker: SWANSON
dialogues.text: I know it sounds crazy, but I got a message from a higher power telling me to shoot Jimmy Hoffa. The camera flashes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank, in his office, on the phone to Jimmy -

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: I was wondering if you and Ed Partin might be able to come down here. There’s a lot of nuts in Nashville.  65

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and another tough Teamster - Louisianan Ed Partin - Jimmy's bodyguards now - tower over the diminutive labor leader, walking alongside him to the courtroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As prosecutor Jim Neal questions a witness in his Tennessee drawl Frank and Partin survey the room for possible nuts. Hoffa meanwhile surveys the faces of the jury -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The legal team’s investigator lays out surveillance photographs of the same people - marked JUROR 1, 2, 3, etc. - like a game of solitaire. On the sofa Ed Partin and Frank watch the unfolding events of the Cuban Missile Crisis on the TV while Jimmy, in his pajamas, makes scrambled eggs for them and Chuckie and the legal team.

dialogues.speaker: INVESTIGATOR
dialogues.text: This one’s married to a state trooper. Jimmy takes a look at the surveillance photo of a woman juror on the table.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Oh, that’s good. (pause) We know anybody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shirtless Ed Partin removes a microphone and tape recorder strapped under his arm and hands it to Jim Neal, the prosecutor we saw in court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deserted stretch of highway. A lone Cadillac parked on the shoulder. A Tennessee State Highway Patrol car pulls over.  66 But rather than what normally happens, a man climbs out of the Cadillac, walks over to the police car, and talks with the trooper. As he hands him an envelope - A long lens camera captures the bribe, the man walking back to the Cadillac, the car driving off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jimmy cooks breakfast for everyone again, we regard the surveillance photographs of the jurors on the table. To one on which someone has already written Patrolman’s Wife, someone adds a check-mark flourish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Caddie driver who rendezvoused with the trooper out on the highway, EWING KING, is called to the stand. As he raises his right hand and is sworn in, Jimmy, at the defense table, subtly lifts his own hand and spreads his fingers. The man nods almost imperceptibly as he sits in the box.

dialogues.speaker: JIM NEAL
dialogues.text: Mr. King, you’re a member of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, is that correct?

dialogues.speaker: EWING KING
dialogues.text: I respectfully decline to answer that under the protection afforded me by the Fifth Amendment.

dialogues.speaker: JIM NEAL
dialogues.text: All I asked you is are you a Teamster.

dialogues.speaker: EWING KING
dialogues.text: I respectfully decline to answer under the (protection) -

dialogues.speaker: JIM NEAL
dialogues.text: Fine. Let me show you a photograph. Neal picks up an Exhibit photo of King at the patrol car.

dialogues.speaker: EWING KING
dialogues.text: I respectfully decline (to) -

dialogues.speaker: JIM NEAL
dialogues.text: I haven’t even shown you yet.  67

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank keeps an eye on everyone in the shop as Jimmy spoons at an ice cream sundae. He’s with his attorneys and Chuckie, but is the only one eating.

dialogues.speaker: SOMEONE
dialogues.text: Oh, my God. They look up to the ice cream parlor staff gathering around a small TV behind the counter. Jimmy cranes his neck but can’t see what’s on it.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: What is it? He gets up to see what’s going on. The attorneys and Chuckie and Frank follow him to the counter and see on the TV that John Kennedy has been shot in Dallas. Frank is stunned. The ice cream parlor workers and patrons start crying. Jimmy and his attorneys don’t. EXT. TEAMSTERS’ WXDC HEADQUARTERS - DAY - 1963 A solemn day. The city’s flags are at half-staff including the Capitol dome. As Jimmy, Frank and Bill emerge from the Teamsters’ headquarters building, Jimmy's trial put on hold by the assassination, a news crew intercepts him.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Mr. Hoffa, will you be attending the president’s funeral?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: I wasn’t invited.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: You don’t have to be invited. A million Americans will be there.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: In that case, I need to check my schedule. Jimmy continues toward his waiting car, trailed by the news crew.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: If you were to go, and were asked to speak, what would you say?  68

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: I'd say Bobby Kennedy is just another lawyer now. Jimmy looks up and sees that like all the other flags in the nation, the flag above Teamsters’ Headquarters is at half-staff.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: (into the building) Sonofabitch. EXT. TEAMSTERS’ WXDC HEADQUARTERS - ROOF - DAY Hoffa supervises guards and building workmen as they busily haul the fluttering stars and stripes back to the top of the flag pole. Frank and Bill Bufalino just watch.

dialogues.speaker: TV IMAGES
dialogues.text: The slain president’s solemn funeral procession that Jimmy isn’t part of.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Jimmy was right. Almost. After the assassination, Bobby’s own vendetta against everybody stopped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy stands before the judge and jury. Frank watches from his usual spot behind Jimmy in the gallery.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: But the prosecutors just kept coming. A year after Dallas, while Bobby was running for the New York Senate, the government still brought a jury tampering and fraud case against him.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Mr. Hoffa, most defendants who stand before this court for sentencing have either violated the property rights or personal rights of other individuals. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You stand here convicted of having tampered with the very soul of this nation. INT. PROSECUTOR NEAL’S OFFICE - DAY Hoffa's prosecutor Jim Neal, reporters, the Judge, FBI agents, and Ed Partin, the teamster who wore the wire against Hoffa, are all celebrating their victory at Hoffa's conviction in Neal’s tiny office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A prison bus roars past on Highway 15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The black bus pulls past the gates of the penitentiary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy Hoffa - Inmate No. 33298-NE - is fingerprinted and photographed and given a blue denim prison uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a shopgirl wraps the sterling silver gifts Irene and Carrie have chosen in silver wedding paper, Russell talks with the store owner with Frank at his side -

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: You know, everybody likes to shop in your store but your son is “s'feigatta.” He’s acting wild. You can't control him, you know, there's nobody's going to want to come into your shop anymore. And that’s not good for you and it’s not good for me, it’s not good for anybody. You gotta, you gotta, take control of this kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A glass partition separates Jimmy from his lawyer Bill Bufalino and his pension fund lawyer, ALLEN DORFMAN. They’re on the visitor phones.  70

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Jimmy set it all up. Fitz was running things alright, but that was for show. Fitz got his orders from Jimmy through Bill and Allen Dorfman who ran Jimmy’s loans.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Where is he? He’s late. Bill and Dorfman look at the ceiling. Finally Frank “Fitz” Fitzsimmons comes in and sits down next to Bill and Dorfman, taking a phone.

dialogues.speaker: FITZ
dialogues.text: Sorry I’m late. We’ve got a lot going on.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Fitz's main qualification was he was weak. Jimmy could control him. He liked to drink and play golf and that was about it.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GOLF COURSE
dialogues.text: Fitzsimmons whacks a golf ball off a tee. The other golfers in his group are mobsters, including Tony Pro.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: As much as Jimmy was getting pissed at Fitz, everybody else liked him, cause they got things out of Fitz they could never get out of Jimmy. It’s what happens when you go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell at dinner with Frank.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: We like Fitz, but Jimmy’s got that ball busting Dorfman holding up loans that Fitzie already okayed. And that Dorfman’s one tough Jew. Which Frank takes as his order to get rid of Dorfman. He nods, he’1l take care of it.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: No. No. Just put a firecracker up Dorfman’s ass. That’s all. Fitz will get the message. If you did it to Fitz, that lush would run to the Feds and screw everything up. EXT. ALLEN DORFMAN’S HOUSE - CHICAGO - DAY - 1967 A garage door opens automatically. Allen Dorfman’s Cadillac backs out. The windows of the Caddie suddenly explode from shotgun blasts. Holes erupt in the body of the car. Dorfman yanks the glove compartment open to get to his gun as the shotgun blasts keep pocking the car. Tires screech and then it’s silent. Dorfman pokes his head up to see a Lincoln driving off, not quite believing he’s not dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cadillac is destroyed. Dorfman is fine and doesn’t even look that concerned anymore, though Fitz does as he nervously regards the shot-up car.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Fitz got the message. He was terrified. After that, anybody who wanted anything from the Pension Fund got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy sitting at a table by himself. A kitchen inmate makes a special ice cream sundae. Jimmy turns to look around.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: But in Lewisburg, Jimmy had the other thing to be concerned about: The Little Guy.  72 EXT. PRO’S MIAMI HOUSE - DAY - 1966 As Tony Pro relaxes by the pool of his Miami house in shorts and unbuttoned linen shirt, a drink and a cigar, playing Greek rummy with some guys amidst statuary of wild animals and cherubs and nudes, some FBI agents approach with their badges out.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: They got Pro for extortion and gave him seven years. And by now things had got tense between him and Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kitchen inmate delivers the ice cream sundae to Jimmy at his table.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: This is a work of art, Pete. Thank you. The kitchen inmate leaves to let him enjoy it. Jimmy takes a bite, savoring the ice cream. But then, spoiling the moment, Pro sits at the table with his tray of food, in a prison uniform now instead of pool attire.

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: I got to talk to you about a problem I got with my pension.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: You know? What do you know?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: I know it’s a million-two and there’s a problem with it.

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: So you'll look into it for me.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: There’s nothing to look into. It’s what it is.

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: What is it?  73

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: You lost it. You forfeited it when you came here.

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: Yours is forfeited, too?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: No. Pro can’t imagine why his pension is gone and Jimmy’s isn’t, but Jimmy doesn’t elaborate, just eats his ice cream. Eventually -

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: Yours is still there. Your million-five or whatever it is.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: We're both sitting here.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: We’re both sitting here for different things. You’re sitting here for extortion. I’m sitting here for fraud.

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: So that’s the difference.

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: What's the difference.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: I didn't threaten anybody, you did.

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: So what? That makes no sense.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: It does if you think about it.

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: It doesn’t, but I don’t want to debate. Just do something about it.  74

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: There’s nothing I can do.

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: There’s always something you can do.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: It's Federal law.

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: I don’t care. You can still do something about it.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: I can’t. What can I do.

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: You can get me my fuckin money.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: Some other way.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: What way.

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: The same way you got your money.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: I earned my money.

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: You’re here for fraud. You stole money. I stole money. Okay, ina different way. Fine. Still. I want what I’m owed.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: You people.

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: What did you say?  75

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: I can’t help you.

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: You people, you said. What does that mean, you people.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: I’m done talking about this.

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: You people? Jimmy ignores him. Eats his ice cream like Pro’s not there. Suddenly Pro lunges across the table, and grabs him. They tumble to the floor and fight until the guards get there to break it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As LBJ looks on, Ramsey Clark raises his right hand to be sworn in as Attorney General.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: With Bobby gone, Ramsey Clark got upped to Attorney General.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank, Skinny, Russell and the rest of the regulars are watching Ramsey Clark questioned by a Senator on the bar TV.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY CLARK
dialogues.text: Public safety will not be found in wiretapping. Security is to be found in excellence in law enforcement, in courts and in corrections - not wiretapping. Nothing so mocks privacy as the wiretap and electronic surveillance. They are incompatible with a free society.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR
dialogues.text: So in your judgment, the enactment of this bill will in no way affect your department’s war on organized crime?

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY CLARK
dialogues.text: That’s correct.  76 Cheers erupt, glasses are lifted, the mobsters shouting ‘To Pamsey,’ and, ‘We love you, Pamsey.’

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: You know what this means. We can speak English on the phone again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lincoln flies past a highway sign: Columbus 64, Dayton 86, Detroit 272.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell in a phone booth talking to someone. Frank paying an attendant for gas and getting a receipt, glancing over there. The wives off smoking by the highway of this gas station with nothing else around it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and Russell at Russell’s usual table.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: That crazy bastard thinks he can do that right there in Columbus Circle in front of 5,000 people and get away with it? That’s not right. You hear me Frankie?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: He was right. Who else runs around with show business people like he’s Errol Flynn, getting his picture in the papers, drawing attention to everybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unlike every other organized crime figure the McClellan Committee has dragged in, Joe Gallo has gone out of his way to look the part - black shirt, slicked-back hair, dark glasses, pinky ring, smoking a cigarette - playing to the news cameras during his testimony.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: He was known downtown as “Joey the Blonde”, but everybody, especially the newspapers, called him “Crazy Joe”.  77

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR
dialogues.text: Mr. Gallo, do you have an opening statement?

dialogues.speaker: GALLO
dialogues.text: (looking down at the carpeting) Yeah. This rug would be great for a crap game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank sitting where we left him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Right then, you knew it was all gonna fall apart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crazy Joe gets out of a car with his new young wife, actor friends, and bodyguard Pete the Greek. Flashbulbs pop. He signs a couple of autographs. He jokes with those on line as he and his entourage enter swept in by Copa doormen.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (IN SYNC)
dialogues.text: He went against everything and he didn’t give a damn. Growing up, he kidnapped his own bosses. I don’t even know how he lived after that. When he went away he recruited black guys instead of his own kind, and when he got out, nobody knew what he was doing or who he was doing it with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An Italian-American Unity Day rally. 5,000 people. Italian flags, American flags. Italian-American Civil Rights League signs and buttons.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (IN SYNC)
dialogues.text: You don’t like what he’s doing? Say something... As Joe Colombo gets up to speak at the podium, a black man walks up and shoots him in front of his family, and is in turn shot by Colombo’s men.  78

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (IN SYNC)
dialogues.text: --- and see what happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An Italian-American Civil Rights League pin with a diamond in it, worn by Russell, who’s with Frank at a table. DON RICKLES is in the middle of a set.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: Who does that? I tell you who does that. Nobody. Like him and Oswald, that’s it. And even in Dallas it was just Jackie there, not the kids.

dialogues.speaker: DON RICKLES
dialogues.text: -..-That’s how I get hired. I work everybody. I work Jews. I work Blacks. I work Gypsies. I work Italians. (seeing Gallo) Uh oh! (points) Not those Italians. (waves ) Hiya! Joey! Hiya! Cent’anni! L’Chaim! Au Salud! (aside to crowd) I was told to be very careful of what I said. Gallo feigns anger and grabs a champagne bottle from a bucket and pretends to throw it.

dialogues.speaker: DON RICKLES
dialogues.text: (hands in prayer) No! Please. It’s okay, Joey, I got the money. Don’t shoot me. Madonna Mia. Maaa! Maaaaa! Gallo laughs and puts the bottle back.

dialogues.speaker: DON RICKLES
dialogues.text: (waves shyly) Happy birthday, Joey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The show’s over. Gallo walks past Russell’s table. Frank is standing by Russell. Gallo nods respectfully. Russell raises a glass.  79

dialogues.speaker: GALLO
dialogues.text: Hey Russ, (taps Russell’s pin) What’re you doing with that? You really believe in that bullshit league?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Joey, that’s nothing to talk about here.

dialogues.speaker: GALLO
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: He’s a boss.

dialogues.speaker: GALLO
dialogues.text: (laughs ) So he’s a boss. So am I a boss. We're all supposed to be brothers.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Joey, let’s not have a beef. Gallo walks off. Russell looks at Frank looking at Joey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Various calibers of pistols laid out on a bed.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: For something like this you want two guns: The one you intend to use, and a backup. Frank regards the guns while the man who gathered them - red-haired John Francis - waits.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: You want something with more stopping power than a .22. (moves the .22s aside) You certainly don’t want a silencer. You want noise to send the witnesses running so they’re not looking at you. (moves the silencers aside) But not the noise a .45 makes that you could hear in a patrol car blocks away. (moves the .45s aside) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The cops call a .32 a woman’s gun because it’s easier to handle and doesn’t do the damage a .38 does, but it does enough. He picks up a .32 anda .38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little Italy on a mid-evening Spring night.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: It would be late so the tourists from Idaho would be in bed. And being in Little Italy would relax him. We - our POV - find and enter Umberto’s Clam House - INT. UMBERTO’S CLAM HOUSE - NIGHT - 1972 The POV regards the interior - the two entrances on Mulberry and Hester - the arrangement of tables - like making a mental diagram of the place.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: It was his birthday, so he'd be there with his wife and kid, which in this case, is the point. They should have to see what it’s like. A waiter comes past with plates of spaghetti with clam sauce.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: He'd have some champagne in him, which would slow him down a little. The POV finds the only empty table, a reserved card on it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: His bodyguard would be with him, and he himself might be carrying too, but it’d probably be in the wife’s purse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Francis’s car, heading into Manhattan.  81

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: You never got a lot of advance notice. And all you knew was your part of it, since three people can keep a secret only if two of them are dead. INT. JOHN FRANCIS’S CAR - MOVING - NIGHT - 1972 Frank and John Francis, not talking as John drives.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: John the Redhead only knew he was going to drop me off, circle the block, and pick me up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's 4:00 am. Umberto’s Clam House is the only place open this late. Crazy Joey’s Lincoln pulls up in front. He climbs out with his wife Sina, her 12-year-old daughter Lisa, his sister, and his bodyguard.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: You want to take out the body- guard first. Not kill him, just disable him. You got no argument with him, so not in the face or chest. The Gallos and the bodyguard disappear into Umberto’s.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Sometimes with something like this you want to go to the bathroom first. John Francis pulls the car to the curb a block away. Frank gets out and the car pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: It gives you a chance to make sure nobody followed you in. It also gives you a chance to make sure nobody’s in the bathroom you have to worry about. Frank walks toward Umberto’s Clam House.  82

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: It also gives you a chance to go to the bathroom. You don’t want to be uncomfortable. Frank opens the Mulberry Street door of Umberto’s -

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: But I went before and in a place this small, this late, you may as well just get to work. INT/EXT. UMBERTO’S CLAM HOUSE - NIGHT - 1972 Frank steps inside. Notes the bodyguard at one table, and Gallo, his wife and sister and the little girl at another. Frank walks toward the tables and shoots Pete the Greek in the thigh with the .38. Gallo’s wife and sister dive for cover, pulling the girl down with them. Gallo pushes away from the table. Frank fires, hitting him in the elbow. As he runs for the door, Frank shoots him in the back. He collapses on the sidewalk and Frank puts two more in him, then walks up the block just as John Francis pulls around it. He gets in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank throws the .38 into the Hudson while John Francis waits in the car. INT. FRANK’S HOUSE - MORNING - 1972 A TV report on the hit at Umberto’s. Frank's not watching it, he’s making cornflakes.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES 0/S
dialogues.text: Peggy, let’s go. Frank turns and sees Peggy, now about 22, behind him. Neither says anything about the news report or anything else. She just leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank washes his hands in the men’s room. Comes out and past Russell on a pay phone.  83 He can’t be sure but it seems Russell maybe stops talking to whoever he’s talking to until Frank is out of earshot. He joins Irene and Carrie at a table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy is escorted down the cell block by guards.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: What can I say. The guy organized a prison. Give him six more months in there and he would have got them a pension plan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy's lawyer, Bill Bufalino, stands with his client before reporters and photographers as he’s released from prison.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: The first thing I’m going to do is register with the Federal Probation Office, as I’m required to do. Then I’m going down to Florida with my wife to get some sun.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Any plans after that?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Yeah. Take back control of my union.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank waits at the pick-up counter of a hotdog place. A TV by the grill - like every TV in America - reports on the arrest of burglars at the Watergate.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: And the first thing I did was pick us up some chili dogs from Lums, which Jimmy loved almost as much as ice cream. Frank watches as his order is being cooked.  84

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: The secret is they steam them in beer. There’s not a better hotdog in America. INT. JIMMY’S CONDO - MIAMI - DAY - 1972 The Watergate break-in report on the TV here, too, as Frank and Jimmy eat their chili dogs. But Jimmy’s less interested in that than the current Teamsters newsletter he’s reading. Jo, just in from the pool, is making herself some lunch.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: What am I going to do with Fitz. He tosses the newsletter to Frank. A cover photo shows Fitzsimmons accepting some award.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He actually thinks he runs things? I appointed him! He didn’t win any election! Now he thinks he’s somebody? Accepting fuckin awards? Jo comes over with her lunch to join them.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: He’s very popular with certain people.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Of course he is! He loans money to every goombah who asks. If the banks did that - can you imagine? - we'd have a financial crisis.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It don’t matter. You run against Fitz and you win hands down.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: You’ve got the Southwest and Central locals locked up. All you need is enough votes in the Northeast and you can win it all.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (to Jo, offering her a chili dog as Hoffa continues to talk) Sure you don’t want one?  85

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: No. No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Yeah, I just can’t believe I’ve got to go to that prick Tony Pro to get them. Frank nods, but his silence says something.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: What.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Like I said, Fitz is popular.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Wiseguys don’t run this union!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: With Fitz, they do.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: But once you’re back as President you can fire anybody, right? You can even fire Tony Pro.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: You can even watch him clean out his desk so he doesn’t steal the pencils.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: (to Frank) See that. Everybody thinks she’s the nice one and that I’m the bad guy. (kisses her cheek) It's just the opposite. I’m the nice guy and she’s the killer. I hate I gotta deal with that cocksucker - he’s fucked everything up.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHCUT TO
dialogues.text: Tony Pro attacking Jimmy over the ice cream in the prison cafeteria - And right back here, to the CONDO -  86

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: I_know that cocksucker is campaigning for Fitz on the sly.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It's because of his pension.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Because of the pension he doesn’t deserve.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: He still got a lot of votes over there.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Because of me! I gave him that power! Now I got to make peace with the cocksucker? I gotta ask him to endorse me? I hate the idea of that.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Without Pro’s locals, Fitz loses.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: There’s no doubt about that. Jimmy tries to picture sitting down with Pro, and it’s enough to ruin his otherwise nice Lum’s lunch.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: If I sat down with him, would you come along?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and Jimmy wait at a table for Tony Pro to show up. Jimmy checks his watch. Looks at Frank.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Fuck it. Let’s go.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Let’s give him a few more minutes.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: This isn’t right. You don’t do this. You don’t make a man wait.  87

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: The only time you do is when? When you want to say something. When you want to say, Fuck you. That's the only time. Frank nods. They wait, Jimmy getting madder by the second. Finally, a white Cadillac pulls up out front and Pro, wearing shorts and a short-sleeve shirt, comes in with his cousin-in-law ‘Tony Jack’ Giacalone, who, unlike Pro, is wearing enough clothes to conceal a piece, and join Jimmy and Frank at the table.

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: Can you believe this weather? People are freezing to death in New York and look at us. It’s 80 outside. It’s perfect. Why we don't live here year-round is what I want to know.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: It’s summer.

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: It’s summer. People aren’t freezing to death in New York.

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: In my mind it’s always 8 degrees in New York. I’m making a point. Jimmy regards Pro’s casual attire and his tan.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: This is how you dress for a meeting?

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: (re: Hoffa’s clothes) This is how you dress in Florida? In a suit?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: For a meeting, if it’s Florida or Timbuktu. And you’re late.  88

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: You're late.

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: There was traffic.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: I’ve never been late for a meeting in my life.

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: (to his cousin-in-law) Wasn't there traffic?

dialogues.speaker: TONY JACK
dialogues.text: There was.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: I’ve never waited for anybody who’s late more than ten minutes.

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: I'd say fifteen. Fifteen is right.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: No. Ten.

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: I don’t think so. Ten is not enough. You have to take traffic into account.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: That is taking traffic into account. That’s why it’s ten.

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: I still say fifteen.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Ten.

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: Fine. We disagree on that.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: More than ten is saying something. Are you saying something to me.  89

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: I’m here. That says what it says. What can I do for you? Jimmy can barely think straight as mad as he is about Pro being late, but eventually collects himself.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: I want to ask you for your endorsement (for) -

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: Wait, before you tell me, let’s get the other thing straightened out.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: I can’t do anything about your pension. Not with Fitz in there. With Fitz there, you should talk to Fitz about it.

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: I did. He says he'll take care of it. No questions asked. You wouldn’t do that, but he will. I meant the other thing.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: The other thing.

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: You know.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: Your apology.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: My apology. For what.

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: For what you said when you were sitting there eating your fucking ice cream like some fucking king. That was an ethnic slur - “you people.” Jimmy just looks at him. Then -  90

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: I‘1l apologize for that - after you apologize for being late - you mother fucking wop cocksucker. Now Pro just looks at Jimmy while Frank shakes his head wearily. Eventually -

dialogues.speaker: PRO
dialogues.text: I’‘1l apologize for being late - after I kidnap your granddaughter, rip her guts out and send them to you in a fuckin envelope. Jimmy goes for him. Frank and Tony Jack try to pull them apart - like the guards did in the prison cafeteria - but, just like then, it isn’t easy. INT. CAR —- MOVING - MIAMI - DAY Frank drives Jimmy back to his condo after the disaster with Pro. They drive in silence. Then -

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: You think Russell would do something about the Little Guy?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: That would be complicated.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: I know, but maybe you could talk to him. Have a conversation. See what he says.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and Russell climb out of Frank’s car and head for a storefront on 115th Street - the Palma Boys Social Club - outside which some Genovese guys hang out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and Russell share a table with Anthony Fat Tony Salerno.

dialogues.speaker: SALERNO
dialogues.text: I don’t approve of what Pro said to Jimmy. Who talks like that about a man’s grandchildren? That’s not right. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: SALERNO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But Pro isn’t nobody, Jimmy knows that. I’m not going to tell him what he can and can’t say.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: He’s very upset, I understand.

dialogues.speaker: SALERNO
dialogues.text: I’m sure he is. But Jimmy says things too he shouldn’t sometimes. Somebody should calm him down. Frank looks to Russell.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I don’t know what to tell him to calm him down.

dialogues.speaker: SALERNO
dialogues.text: I don’t know if it will calm him down but you can tell him I always liked him and won’t stand in his way trying to get his job back. INT. HOFFA’S DC HOTEL ROOM - DAY - 1972 The TV is on, but Jimmy and Frank aren’t watching it.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: That doesn’t calm me down. Not standing in my way is not the same as doing something about a fucking out of control lunatic.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: He’s not nobody, The Little Guy.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: He’s a cocksucker. Fitz is a cocksucker. I’11 deal with both these cocksuckers myself. EXT. TEAMSTERS’ WXDC HEADQUARTERS - DAY - 1973 Jimmy, always a magnet for reporters, stands outside what used to be his office building, giving a televised interview.  92

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: This used to be my office. Frank Fitzsimmons travels around the country to every goddamn golf course there is. Who is he to run around with Nixon and the Attorney General?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GOLF COURSE
dialogues.text: Fitz plays golf with Richard Nixon, John Mitchell and Tony Pro.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA, (OVERLAP)
dialogues.text: He does this and collects a full- time salary. How do you do that? There’s not enough hours in a day. I went to prison for fraud; this is fraud what he’s doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man and his wife walk along a dock carrying fishing tackle and a cooler.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Fitz responded to Jimmy by sending a message to Jimmy’s old friend, Dave Johnson. As they near their 45-foot cabin cruiser, it suddenly blows up - INT. HOFFA’S DC HOTEL ROOM - NIGHT - 1973 A report on the TV shows the aftermath of the Dave Johnson boat bombing. To Frank -

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: This is how Fitz says he wants Dave to step down so his son can run Local 299? By blowing up Dave's boat? This is how I say no to Little Fitz. EXT. NEMO’S BAR - DETROIT - EVENING - 1973 Fitz and his adult son Richard comes out of Nemo’s Bar. As they walk toward Little Fitz's white Lincoln, it blows up, knocking them both off their feet.  93

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josephine Hoffa puts personal items from her desk into a file box.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA, (OVERLAP)
dialogues.text: This is how Big Fitz says he doesn’t like who I say runs the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts the file box in the trunk of her car and climbs in behind the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA, (OVERLAP)
dialogues.text: Firing my wife from her forty- eight-fucking-thousand-dollar-a year union job? Her hand shakes as she turns the key in the ignition, but the car doesn’t blow up. INT. HOFFA’S DC HOTEL ROOM - NIGHT - 1973 Jimmy paces back and forth, a ginger ale in his hand, paying no attention to the Watergate hearings on the TV.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Fine. Fuck them all. Frank is a little distracted by the Watergate witness. E. Howard Hunt according to the TV chyron.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: What’re you looking at.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It's Big Ears.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: What? Who? His ears don’t look so big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy is the guest on a news program.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Frank Fitzsimmons has sold this union out to his underworld pals. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The mob controls him, which means it controls our Pension Fund. I’m talking about a billion dollars in low and no-interest loans this man has given to known racketeers for their illegal enterprises. Not anymore. It’s time the rats abandoned ship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salerno, Russell and Frank at Salerno’s table again.

dialogues.speaker: SALERNO
dialogues.text: Is he serious?

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: He doesn’t mean any of this.

dialogues.speaker: SALERNO
dialogues.text: Maybe he got religion in prison.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: He didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: SALERNO
dialogues.text: People do. Remember Whispers. The other Whispers.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: Not Jimmy. It’s all for the publicity. He’s running for office. He’s putting on a show.

dialogues.speaker: SALERNO
dialogues.text: I don’t know. When I hear a thundering stampede I think of getting run over by hoofs. Maybe he means what he says.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: He’s campaigning. He’ll say anything.

dialogues.speaker: SALERNO
dialogues.text: I don’t care. I don’t like it. It's no good. Talking like that. Maybe he should cash in that pension and spend more time with his grandchildren. Like the last time, Salerno looks to Frank.  95

dialogues.speaker: SALERNO
dialogues.text: Word should get back to him. INT. HOFFA’S DC HOTEL ROOM - NIGHT - 1973

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Who said that?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It doesn’t matter. It was said.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Was it Russell?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Was it the Little Cocksucker from the Miami Fiasco?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Then who.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: The other Tony.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Which other Tony? They’re all named Tony. What’s the matter with Italians - they can only think of one name.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Salerno. That Tony means something to Jimmy. It gives him pause. But not enough to convince him to change what he’s doing.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: I don’t care who said it, they’re not going to shut me up. Somebody can tell him that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back at the same table with Salerno and Russell. Fat Tony looks at Frank -  96

dialogues.speaker: SALERNO
dialogues.text: He said that? (Frank nods) Before he says things like that, he should remember: Crazy Joe liked to make a lot of noise too. Somebody should tell him that. INT. HOFFA’S DC HOTEL ROOM - NIGHT - 1973 Jimmy eating some room service ice cream. Watergate hearings on the TV.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: He said that? This fuckin guinea said that? That does it. I’m never retiring. Somebody can tell him that.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I have, Jimmy. Over and over.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Then there’s nothing more to talk about. Let me enjoy my ice cream. Jimmy spoons at his ice cream. Frank glances at the TV, though not really to watch it. Eventually -

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: What.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: You’re thinking something. What is it?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It’s not the right time.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: What isn’t.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (pause) The Local’s putting together a testimonial dinner for me. I was thinking of asking if you might present the award.  97

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Who’s going to be there?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Everybody.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Tony, Tony, Tony and Tony.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (nods ) Everybody from Downtown. Jimmy knows he won’t exactly be safe at a place with “everybody” there.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It's not a good idea right now. I understand.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: No, I don’t give a fuck who’s there. They’re not going to keep me away from your big night. These cocksuckers. You deserve this. I’d be honored. I’1l1 be there. Jimmy thinks about it a moment longer, then glances to the TV. John Dean testifying, his wife sitting stoically behind him.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Good looking broad, that Mo Dean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Vegas-style supper club looks like it was plucked off Fremont Street and dropped here, but in fact was just moved five miles from Philly across the Delaware River. Usually it’s someone like Al Martino or Dean Martin or Liberace on the marquee, but tonight it reads: ‘Frank Sheeran Appreciation Night.’

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We come past a poster on an easel with Frank’s picture on it and make our way into a banquet room, past an open bar, follow waiters serving dinner to 1,500 people. At the microphone -  98

dialogues.speaker: MCCULLOUGH
dialogues.text: We've got a great turnout for Frank tonight, because Frank's a man with a lot of friends. From his army buddies who fought with him in Italy under General George Patton, to the drivers, national organizers, business agents, local presidents, joint council chairmen and regional trustees. Tonight, we're all “Friends of Frank’s"”, like NAACP president, Cecil Moore; District Attorney, Emmett Fitzpatrick; Philadelphia Mayor, Frank Rizzo... As he continues introducing the dignitaries on the dais with Frank, a title comes up on screen -— Roofers Union President John McCullough, shot six times in the head in his kitchen, 1980.

dialogues.speaker: MCCULLOUGH
dialogues.text: And of course, our featured speaker, James Riddle Hoffa. Meanwhile, outside, in the trees, we've got the FBI.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waiters sets down plates of prime rib in front of - Russell, Angelo Bruno, Tony Salerno and Tony Pro and their wives at one table. Skinny and other mid-level Philly guys and their wives at another. Frank's wife Irene and his four grown daughters at another table with Jimmy’s wife Jo and theirs, Barbara and James P. Hoffa, and foster son Chuckie - Irene and Jo marveling at how big each others’ kids have gotten. Russell and Salerno regard Jimmy cutting into his prime rib on the dais next to Frank.

dialogues.speaker: SALERNO
dialogues.text: He’s not even the goddamn president and he’s holding up people’s loans.  99

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: We sure? How?

dialogues.speaker: SALERNO
dialogues.text: He’s using his pension fund trustees - his guys to hold back loans for a new hotel in New Orleans for Carlos and loans to build up Caesar’s on the Strip.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: What about Fitz? He’s gotta be able to help.

dialogues.speaker: SALERNO
dialogues.text: The money comes through the trustees. They gotta sign off. They’re supposed to rubber stamp whatever Fitz says, except Jimmy’s got a couple of them to stop rubber stamping.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch.

dialogues.speaker: SALERNO
dialogues.text: He said to somebody, once Fitz is out and he’s in, he’s going to call in old loans. Real estate, casinos, whatever it is, you don’t pay him the full thing and interest in two seconds, he’s taking them over.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: He said that?

dialogues.speaker: SALERNO
dialogues.text: Who does he think he is, Castro? Hoffa can’t hear what they’re saying down there, but doesn’t shy from looking them in the eye when they look up at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As dessert is served, a line of fishnet-stockinged dancers high-kick on stage. Peggy, at the Sheeran family table, glances from the dancers to a corner of the room Russell has found where he can speak to Jimmy in confidence.  100

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: I don’t understand why you’re doing this. You don’t need the money.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: It’s not about money.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: Then I don’t understand what all this talk is about.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: It’s my union.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: I don’t know. It seems maybe it’s about something else. Nothing from Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: Some people - not me - are a little concerned. Some people - not me - feel you - might be -

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Might be -

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: Demonstrating a failure to show appreciation.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: I’m not showing appreciation?

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: Some people - not me - might think so.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: I went to school for five fuckin years. I didn’t name one fuckin name.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: I know. Jimmy glances over to where Tony Pro is talking to Salerno at his table.  101

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: I had to sit there listening to that whining cocksucker from New Jersey when all I wanted was to eat my ice cream in peace.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: This cocksucker shows up to a meeting fifteen minutes late in fucking shorts. Who wears shorts to a meeting?

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: I’m not showing appreciation?

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: According to some people - not me.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Fuck them. Nobody threatens Hoffa. As Jimmy walks away, everything in room slows down. From the dais, Frank watches, more than a little concerned.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Jimmy shouldn’t have walked away first. He should have let Russell walk away. Russell just stands there, looking after Jimmy, no doubt thinking the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell, Salerno and Pro watch Jimmy up at the podium, finishing his presentation to Frank -

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Frank has devoted his life to this union. As a driver, as an organizer, as a mediator - he’s been tireless in his service to the working men and women of this country. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He also holds a record you may not know, which I don’t think anybody will ever beat: Most arrests on a picket line - 26 times in 24 hours - beating my record! The guests applaud and laugh.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: I’ve known Frank a long time. I respect him. I rely on him. He is a union man to his bones, and he’s my friend. I’m honored to present this award - and this beautiful watch - to Frank Sheeran. Frank joins him at the podium as everyone applauds. Jimmy straps a gold diamond-encrusted watch on his wrist, pats him on the back, turns the microphone over to him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Thank you, Jimmy. Thank you all. Thank you to my wife Irene and my lovely daughters, Maryanne, Dolores, Connie - Peggy - for putting up with me all these years. Three of his daughters are smiling. Peggy isn’t.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: And to Jimmy. I can’t tell you what this means to me to get this honor from you. Jimmy’s the only guy to get the job done and I promise all my support and help to you, Jimmy. (mild applause) Russ bet me I was going to mess up my speech... so all I can say is, thank you all from the bottom of my heart. I know I don’t deserve all this tonight. But I have bursitis and I don’t deserve that either. (laughs ) See Russ, I didn’t mess up my speech. Everyone laughs.  103

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A photographer motions Frank and Jimmy to stand together for a picture -

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Look at all these people who came out for you. Even the mayor. I truly had no idea you were this strong.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It’s a free steak and an open bar.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: No, they’re here for you, my friend. The camera flashes.

dialogues.speaker: PHOTOGRAPHER
dialogues.text: Couple more, please.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I’m sorry Pro's here.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: You have no control over that. The camera flashes.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: I really do appreciate all the support you've given me, Frank. I mean it. It’s not just words. I’m glad you're on my side. Frank forces a smile for the photographer as the camera flashes again taking a photo of Frank with Jimmy, another with Cecil Moore, another with Mayor Rizzo, another with Jimmy’s kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry Vale’s singing ‘Spanish Eyes’ as couples dance. Jimmy’s dancing with Frank’s daughter Peggy, and each time they turn, she looks over at - Russell and Salerno looking right at her - or rather at Jimmy - as they quietly converse at their table. Salerno doesn’t look happy, gets up and leaves, followed by Pro.  104

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back at the Sheeran family table, Peggy’s watching her father with Russell who have found a semi-private spot to talk across the room.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: I didn’t want to do this in front of everybody. He hands Frank a small jewelry box. Inside it, Frank finds a gold ring with a gold coin on top.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: Only three people in the world have one of these, and only one of them is Irish. I have one. Angelo. And now you. (pause) You know what this means. Frank does. It’s as close to a made-man any non-Italian will ever get.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I don’t know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: Put it on. Let’s see if it fits. Frank slips the ring on. It fits. Jerry Vale starts another song.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: There’s something else. It just got out of hand with your friend. Some people have a serious problem with him. Talk to your friend. Tell him, it’s what it is. Frank isn’t sure he heard right.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It’s what it is?

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: Yeah. Talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I’1l do my best. You know yourself, Russ; he’s tough to talk to.  105

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: He’s got no choice. It comes from high up.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Jimmy's pretty high up himself.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: You’re dreaming, my friend. If they can take out the President they can take out the president of a union. And, as it’s supposed to work, Russell walks away first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the dancing continues, Frank and Jimmy, off by themselves, talk.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I just spoke to Russell. He just spoke to Tony. He means what he’s saying.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Who? Russell?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Tony.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Well, I mean what I say. He can’t seem to get that through his fat fuckin Sicilian head. Jimmy notices how ashen-faced Frank looks.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Don’t look so concerned.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I’m a little concerned.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: They should be concerned, not you.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: They are. They’re more than a little concerned. There's widespread concern. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tony told Russell to tell me to tell you what it is. Jimmy looks at Frank a bit stunned finally.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: They wouldn’t dare.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Don’t say that, Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Something funny happens to me, I got stuff ready to go. To the press. To the right people. They do something to me, something is gonna be done to them, and those guinea motherfuckers know that. They know I know things that I know. They know I know things they think I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Jimmy, what am I supposed to do. I got to go back and tell the old man - what. That you’re still not listening to him? He ain’t used to people not listening to him.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Neither am I. Frank has run out of ways to make him see.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Then I don’t know, you should maybe keep some bodies around for protection.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: I’m not going that route, they could go after my family. You should keep some bodies around, they could go after you since you’re with me. Frank isn’t sure who he’s with anymore, so caught in the middle.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Tell Russ I got nothing but respect for him. I would never hurt him. But this is my union.  107 Jimmy leaves him to go to the Sheeran family table.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: You know what I love, Peggy?

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Ice cream.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: More than ice cream. You. Let’s dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy dancing with Peggy. Frank, at his family’s table now, watches them, a more-than-a-little-concerned look on his face, though Peggy, noticing it, can’t imagine why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same concerned look on Frank’s face here. Then -

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: The wedding was all well and good, but the real point of our trip to Detroit was a peace mission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An attendant checks the oil. The women are buying cigarettes from a machine while Russell buys some candy from another. Frank’s making a call in a phone booth. INTERCUT with Jimmy at his Lake Orion house outside Detroit.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I’m with the old man. We’re driving up. He hopes this thing can be worked out.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: What’d he say?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: He said let’s work this thing out. Sit down after the wedding and work it out.  108

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: I’m not going to the wedding. Too many people I don’t like are going to be there.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: We could do it at your place if you want.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: At the lake, huh.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Or anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: From day one I wanted to work this out.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: From day fucking one.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Just you two, right? Not the Little Guy.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Of course the Little Guy.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: No. Just the three of us.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: There’s no point just the three of us.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: I’m not sitting down with that cocksucker.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It's time to sit down, Jimmy. Everybody says so.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Not with him.  109

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You’re making me work hard.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Just us. Jimmy hangs up. Frank lets himself out of the booth. Russell comes over unwrapping a candy bar.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: What’d he say?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: He’s thinking about it.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: That’s good. That’s progress. You want half of this Milky Way? EXT/INT. HOWARD JOHNSON’S - OHIO - DAY - 1975 The Sheerans and Bufalinos checking into a Howard Johnson's motel. INT. HOWARD JOHNSON’S - OHIO - LATER - DAY - 1975 Russell hangs up a pay phone and crosses a patio past Irene and Carrie wading in the pool with swimming caps on to where Frank’s at a patio table with a Tab, sits.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: You should give Jimmy another call, don’t you think? See if he’s thought about it. INT. HOWARD JOHNSON’S - OHIO - LATER - DAY - 1975 Frank on the same pay phone near the pool Russell was on, again INTERCUT with Jimmy at his Lake Orion house -

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: When you getting in?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Tomorrow morning.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Good. I changed my mind about the other thing.  110

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You did?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: I’m meeting with the Little Guy tomorrow afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: With the Little Guy.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Tony Jack set it up.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: With the Little Guy. Where?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: In public, where do you think. The Red Fox. On Telegraph. You know it?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Tony Jack is Pro’s cousin.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: They’re all fucking cousins, what are you going to do. But Jack's okay. I talked with him several times after the Fiasco-In- Miami.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I'd feel better if I was there.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: So would I, that’s why I asked when you're getting in.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What time’s the meeting?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: 2:30, and he better not be late. Or wearing fuckin shorts.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: The Red Fox.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: On Telegraph. I’11 be there at 2. So you should be there at 2.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I’‘ll be there at 2.  111

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Good. Jimmy hangs up. Frank hangs up, a little puzzled about Jimmy's change of heart. Walks back to the patio table.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: What’d he say?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: He’s going to meet with Pro.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: That’s good.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Tony Jack arranged it.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: That’s good. And that’s it. No other comment. Which Frank finds a little odd after all that’s gone on with this.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Maybe Jimmy was counting on Pro to act like Pro so Tony Jack could see Jimmy being reasonable and Pro being unreasonable like in Miami, and tell Salerno. INT. HOWARD JOHNSON’S MOTEL ROOM - EVENING - 1975 Frank and Irene change into something nice for dinner, like people used to do.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Or maybe this wedding really was bringing everybody together. There’s a knock on the door. Russell and Carrie - dressed nicely, too - Russell holding the bag with a loaf of prosciutto bread in it. As they all leave -

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Whatever it was, you’d think Russell would’ve asked when the meeting was, where it was, whether he was supposed to come or not. Something. The door closes. We remain in the empty motel room.  112

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: But he didn’t ask anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carrie and Irene sit alone at the best table in the restaurant, sipping cocktails and smoking like you used to be able to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell, who owns the place, or part of it, prepares his special salad dressing in the restaurant’s kitchen, mixing olive oil, balsamic and ginger root, the loaf of prosciutto bread next to it.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: By the way, we got a little change in plans. We’re going to hang around here tomorrow morning and drive up in the afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I told Jimmy we'd be there in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: That I’d be at the meeting with him and Pro.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: I know. Frank does okay not showing it, but is reeling from Russell telling him he’s not going to let him be with Jimmy at the meeting.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: We did all we could for the man, Cheech. Russell looks to Frank for a nod that he understands, but Frank doesn’t nod. Russell swirls the salad dressing in the jar around and dips a finger in to taste it.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: Don’t call him.  INT. HOWARD JOHNSON’S MOTEL ROOM - NIGHT - 1975 Frank lies awake in bed next to his sleeping wife, staring at the phone on the night stand next to him. INT. HOWARD JOHNSON’S LOBBY - EARLY MORNING — 113 Frank comes down to the breakfast room. Russell is the only other guest there this early, filling a plastic bowl from an individual-serving box of cornflakes.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: Morning.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: How'd you sleep?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: Want some Total?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Okay. Russell prepares him a bowlful.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: We’re going up to Port Clinton today.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I thought we were staying here.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: The women are staying here. We won't be gone long. Three hours tops. They sit with their cornflakes. Russell eats his. lets his get soggy.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What’s in Port Clinton?

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: A plane. Frank  114

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: A plane. (Russell nods) To where?

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: Detroit. This isn’t making any sense to Frank.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: We’re going to Detroit now?

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: You’re going to Detroit now. Then you're coming back. Then we'll take our time driving up there. Nice leisurely drive. And fuckin cigarette breaks. Frank has no idea what he’s talking about, but doesn’t like it, whatever it is.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: I got to put you into the thing, Frank. Otherwise you'd never let it happen. And it’s gonna happen. Russell looks at Frank like a father to a son.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: Either way, Jimmy will be gone, but this way, and it’s only out of respect for me they agreed to it by the way, everything will be okay for you and Irene, because you’re with me. He eats his cornflakes.

dialogues.speaker: HIGHWAY 80, OHIO
dialogues.text: As Frank drives, Russell sits in the passenger seat looking placidly out at the scenery through his thick glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They drive onto a grass airstrip on the edge of Lake Erie where a small plane waits. Frank parks, shuts it off, leaves the keys in the ignition, gets out. Russell stays in the car.  115 Frank climbs the steps of the plane and sits in one of its six seats. The pilot closes the door without looking at him and returns to the cockpit. As the plane begins to taxi, Frank looks out the window at the Lincoln.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane descends over the north shore of Lake Erie. Lands on the Pontiac Airfield. The pilot lowers the steps and Frank climbs out and walks to a parked Ford that’s empty. He gets in, finds its keys under the mat, starts it up.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. FORD
dialogues.text: Frank drives along Telegraph Road. Opens the glove compartment, notes the little .22 in it, closes it, sees Machus Red Fox restaurant up ahead, checks the gold watch Jimmy presented him with at the Latin Club: 2:05. As he passes the Red Fox, he can see Jimmy sitting in his green Pontiac in the lot. INT. HOFFA’S CAR - PARKED - SAME TIME - 1975 Jimmy doesn’t notice the Ford pass by. He’s looking at his own watch, and beginning to get annoyed Frank is five minutes late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank makes a left onto Seven Mile Road. Drives across a railroad bridge. Then down a residential street with old modest houses on half acre lots. He checks an address scribbled on a Howard Johnson's napkin. Pulls over and regards a brick-and-shingled house. He notes a Buick parked at the end of a single-lane driveway running alongside the house. Opens the glove box and takes out the .22. He gets out of the car, shoves the pistol in his back waist-band under his jacket, climbs the steps of the house and opens the unlocked front door -  116

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man on his hands and knees looks up at Frank through Coke-bottle glasses.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY BUGS
dialogues.text: Hi, Frank. Sally has a matte-knife in his hand and uses it to cut some linoleum he’s laying out on top of the wood floor of the entry.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Sally. Frank surveys the entry. Then walks into the adjacent living room, glimpsing as he goes two young Italian guys in the kitchen down the hall, playing cards. Sally Bugs comes over, parts the living room blinds and looks out.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY BUGS
dialogues.text: Chuckie’s late.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Jimmy’s son Chuckie, his foster son, he was in the thing, too, but didn’t know it. Sally Bugs sees a car pulling to the curb.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY BUGS
dialogues.text: Is that him? It's a maroon Mercury Marquis with just the driver in it. Frank nods.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: All Chuckie knew, he was picking up one of Pro’s guys and me and we were all picking up his dad at the Red Fox for a meeting. Chuckie gets out of the car. Leans against the car, waiting, wearing a wide-collared paisley shirt and gold chains.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: He was in it, as you say, stupidly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 117 Frank and Sally Bugs come out of the house and approach the Mercury.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY BUGS
dialogues.text: I’m Sally.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCKIE
dialogues.text: Hi. Hi, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Chuckie.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY BUGS
dialogues.text: Let’s go. I don’t want your father yelling at me for being late. You can sit in front, Frank. Frank doesn’t want to sit in front. Sally Bugs, we may recall, strangled that poor Teamster Treasurer in a front seat. But Sally already has the car’s back door open and is sliding in.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY BUGS
dialogues.text: The fuck is this?

dialogues.speaker: CHUCKIE
dialogues.text: What.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY BUGS
dialogues.text: It’s wet back here.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCKIE
dialogues.text: I had a frozen fish I had to drop off to someone.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY BUGS
dialogues.text: A fish? The seat is wet from a fish?

dialogues.speaker: CHUCKIE
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I’1l sit back there.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY BUGS
dialogues.text: No, no, no, it’s all right, you take the front.  118 As Frank reluctantly climbs into the front passenger seat, Sally Bugs lays his handkerchief on the back seat and sits on it.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Chuckie makes a right off Seven Mile Road onto Telegraph. Frank is still uneasy, concerned Sally might strangle him from behind.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY BUGS
dialogues.text: What kind of fish.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCKIE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY BUGS
dialogues.text: What kind of fish.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCKIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. A fish. To eat.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY BUGS
dialogues.text: You don’t know what kind?

dialogues.speaker: CHUCKIE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY BUGS
dialogues.text: Where'd you get it?

dialogues.speaker: CHUCKIE
dialogues.text: At a fish place. Frank checks his watch. It’s 2:40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy hangs up a pay phone behind the restaurant and heads for his Pontiac. Wearing a polo shirt and slacks there’s no way he’s carrying a piece. The Mercury honks. Jimmy stares at it a moment, then comes over.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCKIE
dialogues.text: Sorry I’m late.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Late? What the fuck you even doing here? Who invited you?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY BUGS
dialogues.text: Hi, Jimmy.  119

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Who the fuck are you?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY BUGS
dialogues.text: I’m with Pro.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: You're with Pro. You’re with this cocksucker who’s late again? I’m not waiting for this cocksucker again. He was supposed to be here at 2:30. It’s 2:40. I don’t wait for anybody more than ten minutes. Mother fucking cocksucker.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY BUGS
dialogues.text: He’s at the house.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: What house?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY BUGS
dialogues.text: He’s with Russ.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: He’s with Russ ... What the fuck is going on here?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY BUGS
dialogues.text: Look who’s here. Jimmy leans down to see who’s in the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Hi, Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Frank. What the fuck’s going on here? Where were you? You were supposed to be here at two. What is this?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Russell decided to come. But not here. He doesn’t know the place. It’s not comfortable for him.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: McGee is here? In Detroit?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: To help straighten all this out. That changes things. Jimmy relaxes a little.  120

dialogues.speaker: SALLY BUGS
dialogues.text: We'll bring you back after to get your car. Sally Bugs pushes open the back door for Jimmy to get in and the motion slows down -

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: No way in a million years Jimmy would ever get in a car with one of Pro’s guys in it ... unless I was in it, too. Which is why I was in it. I made it safe. The motion returns to normal as Sally Bugs taps the seat next to him.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY BUGS
