dialogues.text: There was a fish in here, but I cleaned it up.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY BUGS
dialogues.text: Chuckie had a fuckin fish in here, he doesn’t even know what kind, but it’s okay now, I wiped it up.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: You put a fish in here? In your car?

dialogues.speaker: CHUCKIE
dialogues.text: For Bobby Holmes. Bobby likes fish.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY BUGS
dialogues.text: I cleaned it up, Jimmy. It’s all right.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: You cleaned it up, the fuck you know about fish? You ever caught a fucking fish in your life?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY BUGS
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Then you don’t know.  121 Jimmy glances off to his own car, then back to Frank again as if to say, Promise me this is okay.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It’s all right. Frank nods. Jimmy finally gets into the back seat next to Sally.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Chuckie, never put a fish in your car, you’ll never get the smell out. Unless it’s wrapped up good.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCKIE
dialogues.text: I know. The Mercury pulls out of the lot. INT. CHUCKIE’S MERCURY - MOVING - DAY - 1975 The Mercury drives the same route Frank took earlier.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Frank. You couldn’t come by at 2:00 and tell me this? I had to wait there forty minutes like a fuckin moron?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I came as soon as I got in.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: You got in this morning.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No. Russell had some business in Port Clinton this morning.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: This morning. Okay. But it’s this afternoon. All due respect to Russ but nobody could come over at 2:00 and tell me it was 2:30? 2:40? At the very least? (like Sally’s not there) And who the fuck is Pro sending a fucking errand boy.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Sally’s not staying.  122

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: That’s right he’s not staying. But Pro sent him is the point I’m making, when he should've come picked me up himself. (to Sally) Can you even see out those glasses?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY BUGS
dialogues.text: I can see, Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mercury pulls into the driveway behind the Buick and the Ford and idles. Jimmy and Frank get out. Sally Bugs comes around and gets into the passenger seat. As Chuckie backs the car out, Jimmy and Frank head for the house. Jimmy - as he always does with whoever he’s with - walks ahead.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: You got your friend with you? Glancing back, he sees Frank touch the small of his back.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Good. You never know with this cocksucker, with or without Russ there. He opens the front door and -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As soon as he’s inside, Jimmy knows there’s a problem. He should hear voices - but it’s quiet. And there’s no one in the living room, which he can see from here in the entry. And there’s this badly-cut piece of linoleum under his feet. The motion slows to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: He knew right away what it was.

dialogues.speaker: FIVE QUICK VIGNETTES, (1975)
dialogues.text: A flurry of feathers: Tony Pro with his racing pigeons on the roof of Union Hall in New Jersey -  123 A Yankees game on a TV: Tony Salerno watching it in the Palma Boys Social Club in East Harlem - A golf ball chipped out of a sand trap: Fitz and Nixon on a golf course in San Clemente - Frank's Lincoln: Russell napping in the parked car on the Port Clinton airstrip - Reflections in the Howard Johnson's pool. Irene and Carrie next to it on chaise lounges, smoking cigarettes - Maybe putting suntan lotion on each other.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Just not my part of it.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFA
dialogues.text: Let’s get out of here, Frank. As Jimmy bumps past Frank to leave, grasping the knob of the door Frank just closed, Frank shoots him twice behind his right ear. He slumps to the floor. Blood runs onto the temporary linoleum. Frank glances down the hall to see if someone is going to come kill him now - which wouldn’t surprise him - but no one appears. Frank tries to open the front door but Jimmy’s body is against it. He gently tugs Jimmy away from it, gets it open, wipes the .22 with a handkerchief and sets it on Jimmy, wipes the door knob, and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane lands, taxis to a stop. The pilot, again careful not to look at Frank, lowers the steps. Frank comes down them and crosses to the Lincoln, where Russell is napping. Frank climbs in, shuts the door. Russell wakes at the sound of it. Just by looking at Frank, he can tell the little errand in Detroit has been taken care of. Frank starts the car and they drive off to pick up their wives at the Howard Johnson's.  124

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teamster lawyer Bill Bufalino - who represented Frank against the meat packing company long ago - and Hoffa in Nashville - escorts his daughter down the aisle. The church is packed with friends and relatives of the bride and groom, union and mob guys, Russell and Carrie with Frank and Irene. Frank just stares straight ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TV broadcasts a news report on Hoffa’s disappearance. He’s been missing a couple days now. Frank comes in from outside, takes his coat off, regards the TV and his wife and daughters who are watching it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Still no word? Irene shakes her head no. Frank pours himself a drink.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I should call Jo.

dialogues.speaker: IRENE
dialogues.text: You haven’t called her yet? Frank shakes his head no. Irene turns back to the TV report. Peggy doesn’t. She studies her father.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Why.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Why what.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Why haven’t you called her. The image of the family slows ...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Maybe it was I looked hard instead of worried. Or that I should have been rushing out to hurt somebody, and wasn’t. Whatever it was, she knew. The image returns to normal.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I’1l call her now.  125 Peggy watches her father turn and head upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (IN SYNC)
dialogues.text: She stopped talking to me that day. August 3rd, 1975.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank looks as thoughtful and concerned as he ever has.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: She’s got a good job and lives outside Philly now but my daughter Peggy disappeared from my life that day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone in his bedroom, Frank sits on the edge of his bed dialing a phone. He can hear the report from downstairs faintly up here as people who know nothing theorize about the disappearance. The call connects.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Jo? It’s Frank. (listens, nods) Whatever you need, anything I can do, I’m here. She’s crying now. He puts the receiver to his head like it’s a gun ... then back to his ear.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It’s gonna be all right. I’m sure he’s all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two Italians who were playing cards in the kitchen carry the body, in a body bag, out the back door and dump it in the trunk of the Buick. They toss in the bloody linoleum and .22 pistol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They lift the body from the trunk and carry it to the back door of a funeral parlor.  126

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Anybody that says Jimmy was shipped in a 55-gallon drum to a dump in New Jersey or to the end zone in Giants Stadium never had a body on their hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They put Jimmy’s body in a cardboard coffin into a cremation oven. Toss in the linoleum and the empty .22. The gas jets burn so hot they turn everything to ash - bones, teeth - even melting the pistol and Jimmy’s watch and wedding ring - and the spent bullets in his head. The furnace finishes. The cinders of the coffin have fallen away to reveal the form of an ashy body, like at Pompeii. The two Italians poke at it with rubber-gloved hands, reducing it to gritty sand-like ashes.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It was no more complicated than that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank is being questioned by an Assistant U.S. Attorney.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Everybody who ever had anything to do with Jimmy was hauled in and questioned. And everybody took the Fifth, which is what you do.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: On the advice of counsel, I respectfully decline to answer that question under the protection afforded me by the Constitution, on the grounds that my answer might tend to incriminate me.

dialogues.speaker: ASST. U.S. ATTORNEY
dialogues.text: Let me ask you this: What color is my pen?  127

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: On the advice of counsel, I respectfully decline to -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and his lawyer head for the back exit.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Still, everybody got indicted and convicted of one thing or another, just not for that. Nobody, as you know, even went to jail for that. And nobody talked. Which is unusual since usually three people can keep a secret only when two are dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two Italians playing cards in the kitchen -

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Bruno Denzetta and Marco Rossi got twenty years for squeezing cash out of a trucking company in exchange for labor peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony Pro walks down a cell block with other inmates -

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Pro was convicted with them, but he was already back in school for that other matter I mentioned before -

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: The man in the passenger seat finds the radio station he wants and sits back.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: That poor union Treasurer Tony Three Fingers who got more votes than Pro, which they finally got Pro on.  128 As the nylon rope loops around the guy’s neck to strangle him, Coke bottle glasses on a face come into frame.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Sally Bugs, you recall, did that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From far away, someone watches Sally Bugs walk from his car to the building.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: One day he was seen walking into the Federal building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell and Frank sitting together at the usual table.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: That by itself isn’t a crime. Everybody gets called in there sometime. But Sally - who knows better - didn’t tell nobody about it. Not a word to anybody. And then, you know, between one thing and another, it meant one thing: He wasn’t going in there for lunch. Frank nods. He knows he’s just been told what to do by not being told not to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sally comes out of the Andrea Doria Social Club on Mulberry Street. Frank and John Francis walk up to him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Hi, Sal.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY BUGS
dialogues.text: Hi, Frank. Sally looks at John Francis, who he doesn’t know. As he waits for an introduction, Frank shoots him twice in the head - one of the bullets shattering a lens of his thick glasses. He hits the ground and John Francis fires three shots into Sally’s belly. As they walk away -  129

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: It turns out Sally did tell somebody he had to go in there. They just forgot to tell somebody else. So it was a bad hit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony Salerno on a surgical table getting a colonoscopy.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Fat Tony Salerno they got on an income tax thing. A little while after he was diagnosed with prostate cancer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell having what seems to be a normal conversation with another man at a table, Jimmy The Weasel Fratianno.

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: You know there’s a pork store in Walnut Creek, California, Jimmy. It's right near where you live. You ever go there?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Russell got hooked for telling Jimmy “The Weasel” to strangle Jack Napoli over 25 grand of jewelry Jack took on credit and never paid for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell is escorted out in cuffs by federal agents.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Only The Weasel flipped. They called it Conspiracy to Killa Witness, though it was Napoli who was clearly in the wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The conveyor draws a 1978 black Lincoln Continental into the car wash tunnel. Overhead nozzles turn on and spray the car with water.  130

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank, hand raised, being sworn in.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: They brought me up on bribery and labor racketeering charges and some other things - A title appears: Murder, Attempted Murder, Intimidation, Embezzlement, Arson Frank in the witness box where he’s been for awhile.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I’m going to say to you one time, I’ve listened to you, now you listen to me. I’ve worked for 44 years, and I never took one dime illegal off Boffa or nobody else. What you think don’t interest me. All I know is I paid him. What he does with the money is his business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silhouettes of some building cranes and other heavy equipment against the night sky outside Baltimore.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: But all they got me for was blowing up the office of a crane company that fired two of my shop stewards for no good reason - The place blows up.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: And for my Lincoln.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank's car inches through the car wash covered in suds.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: I bought it from Eugene Boffa, who leased truck drivers to freight companies and paid them substandard wages, skimming the difference.  131 Frank peers through soapy windows of the car wash at his Lincoln as leather tongues shimmy and sway and push the suds around.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: They said I paid under-market value for the car, and I had no receipts to prove otherwise. They said the car was a bribe to let Boffa continue to pay his non- union wages. Frank watches the Lincoln as spray-hoses rinse it and the dryer blowers switch on.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: I loved that car, but it wasn’t worth the eighteen years they gave me for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A prison set down amidst bare trees in Missouri.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bundled up against the cold, Russell, Salerno and some other old inmates in wheelchairs roll bocce balls on a snow-patched fenced-in rooftop exercise yard.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Russell had a stroke. Fat Tony Salerno couldn’t control his urine anymore. My arthritis that started in the foxholes of Anzio was eating at my lower back now, and I couldn’t feel much in my feet neither. I needed a cane, but they won’t give you a cane in prison since you could use it as a weapon. Neurontin helped a little but it also makes you loopy. Frank, who’s getting no younger himself, watches from the sidelines.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: We were all falling apart in the freezing fucking cold.  132

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank comes in with a paper bag, limps across the cafeteria, sits with Russell. Seeing the bag -

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: You got it. Frank nods. Takes grape juice and prosciutto bread from the bag and begins breaking it into pieces. Eventually -

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: Jimmy was a nice man. Nice family. I didn’t want it to go that far.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I know. Frank pours two glasses of grape juice. Russell's hand tremors a bit as he dips a piece of bread in the juice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank comes out to the exercise yard as Russell in his wheelchair is being pushed by another inmate the other way.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Where you going?

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: To church.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: To what?

dialogues.speaker: BUFALINO
dialogues.text: Don’t laugh, my friend, you'll go too, the time comes. Frank watches Russell as his wheelchair rolls along the frozen ground.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: Russell went to church. Then he went to the prison hospital. Then he went to the graveyard.  133

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The number of people in attendance seems too small for someone of Russell’s stature, which makes sense since it isn’t his funeral.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK V/O
dialogues.text: I got out that October. Irene died in December. December 23rd. Lung cancer. No surprise. Frank stands at his wife’s grave with three of his grown daughters, supporting himself on two aluminum canes like a polio victim. Peggy's there, too, but stands apart from her sisters and father. He looks at her, but she won’t look at him. INT. FRANK’S HOUSE - THAT NIGHT - 1995 Frank moves around the house on his canes, emptying ashtrays of butts with his wife’s lipstick marks on the filters. INT. FRANK’S HOUSE - ANOTHER DAY - 1996 He sits in a chair in front of a TV he’s not watching, drinking wine alone. INT. FRANK’S HOUSE - ANOTHER DAY - 1996 He fills a plastic container marked with the days of the week with dozens of pills, gets confused and starts over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes past in his pajamas to go to the bathroom, negotiating a dark hallway on his canes. Trips and falls and can’t get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elderly men and women, dotting the rec room like checkers on an abandoned board, playing cards and dominoe and Candyland. Frank sits apart from them in a wheelchair, the white shirt, the gold watch, the gold ring, his eyes hidden behind the aviator sunglasses.  134 He’s been here for months. And no one but him is watching the TV with the sound down low: Images of the war in Kosovo. Bombs. Carnage. Death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An orderly assists Frank as he struggles out of a car with his aluminum canes.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I got it. I’m fine. You stay here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes in on his canes. Stands in a short line. Looks around like he’s casing the place. Makes it to the front, but lets someone go ahead of him so he can wait for a particular window. The customer there leaves and he starts toward it. The teller, his daughter Peggy, sees him coming and puts her “closed” sign up before he gets there.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Peggy, don’t. I just want to talk to you. She walks away from the counter toward the back. Goes through a door and closes it. The other customers look at Frank. EXT. DOLORES’S HOUSE - PHILLY - DAY - 2000 The orderly’s car, parked outside a small house. He leans against it, smoking a cigarette. INT. DOLORES’S HOUSE - PHILLY - DAY - 2000 Frank sits with one of his other daughters - Dolores - now in her 40s.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: What do you want me to do about it?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Call her. Tell her I want to talk to her.  135

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: Talk to her and tell her what?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I want to tell her I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: For?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I know I wasn’t such a good father. I tried to be. I tried to protect her. All of you.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: From what? Now that he thinks about it, he’s not sure what.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: You have no idea what it was like for us. We couldn’t come to you with a problem because of what you'd do. We couldn’t go to you for protection because of the terrible things you'd do.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: But I was just trying to keep you from getting hurt. Dolores regards him a moment. He looks helpless. Hapless. Hopeless. Eventually -

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: No. No. You weren’t a bad father. That's what he wants to hear, but by itself, it seems qualified, which it is.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: We were just afraid of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They build them and sell them here. It’s more like a workshop inside a warehouse. The salesman used to be a rock and roll promoter, but now he does this, wearing a porkpie hat.  136

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: I could sell you something for a lot of money but I’1l be honest with you: It makes no sense going with anything more expensive than particle board for cremation. Will it be cremation?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Burial.

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: Okay, that’s going to be more.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: That’s okay. Frank surveys the rows of caskets from his wheelchair, the orderly by his side.

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: Is it for a man or a woman?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It’s for me. His eyes settle on a metal one, green as the green on the Irish flag.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: That one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The orderly again waits for Frank outside, smoking another cigarette, idly looking off at a backhoe digging a grave. He notices a parked black car. Two men in it. Just sitting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A marble wall of mausoleum crypts. Most - the good ones at eye-level or thereabouts - have names on them. A few - the undesirably-placed available ones - are bare.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (IN SYNC)
dialogues.text: We're all terminal. And sooner or later. Everybody put here has a date when he’s gonna go. And I think... it could be... there's gotta be something somewhere. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (IN SYNC)
dialogues.text: There's gotta be something when you go cause how the hell did this whole thing start? What they taught you as a kid? People smarter than me can't figure it out. But there's gotta be something to it. So if there's something good... if it is... I want a shot at it. That’s why I would never go for cremation. It's so final. That’s the hardest part of anybody when they bury is when they go into the ground. Because it's so final. You know what I mean? If you go into a building. The building's there. Your crypt is there. It has to be a metal casket and they have you in the room. And all that there. It's just not as final - you're dead - but it's not as final. Frank stands before them, considering them. There’s no good choice - or bad choice for that matter. A girl from the office with a diagram on a clipboard waits for him to decide. Doesn’t rush him. Finally, he points.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: That one, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same black car from the cemetery parked here now. The two men who were in it - young FBI agents - sit with Frank on the porch of the building. He actually seems fine having them here. At least they’re visitors.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I’m sorry but I have to direct you to my attorney Mr. Ragano if you want to talk about Mr. Hoffa - or any other matter for that Matter. I got nothing new to say.

dialogues.speaker: FBI AGENT
dialogues.text: He’s dead.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Who’s dead?

dialogues.speaker: FBI AGENT
dialogues.text: Your attorney, Mr. Ragano.  138

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: He's dead? Who did it?

dialogues.speaker: FBI AGENT
dialogues.text: Cancer. Frank didn’t know.

dialogues.speaker: FBI AGENT
dialogues.text: Everybody's dead, Mr. Sheeran. Russell, Angelo, Salerno, Pro, Dorfman, Sal Briguglio. But Mr. Hoffa’s children aren’t dead. They live with not knowing, and that’s hard to do. You have children. You know. It’s time to say what happened. Frank actually seems like he might be thinking about telling them. But then -

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You seem like nice fellas. And I appreciate you coming to see me. But I can’t help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank sits in his wheelchair in the chapel of the assisted living facility, a few faded snapshots in his lap. He slowly runs a hand through his hair as he looks at a snapshot of himself with Russell. Eventually - we see that there’s a young priest with him.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Do you still remember the Hail Mary and Our Father?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Say it. See if I do.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Try it. (Frank hesitates) Should I say it?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You say it then (I'll follow) -  139

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Well if you say it, I’1l know whether you remember.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I go so far - “Hail Mary full of grace, Our Lord is with thee -

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: (prompting) Blessed art thou -

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: - amongst women -- That’s about as far as I go.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: You want me to say it?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yeah, why don’t you.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Hail Mary, full of grace. / The Lord is with thee / Blessed art thou among women / And blessed is the fruit of thy womb, Jesus - Frank joins in the prayer, saying it along with the Priest. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK AND PRIEST
dialogues.text: - Holy Mary, Mother of God / Pray for us sinners / Now and at the hour of our death. Amen.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Well, I say what I know - forgive me for not knowing the other half. The intention is there.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: You feel nothing for what you did - (the killings)? [Contrition talk]

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: You don’t feel anything?  140

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I know you’re supposed to feel something. But I guess the fact that I’m here talking to you - that’s something... I guess. It’s a different world where I’m from. There are things you have to do. That's the life you’re in. You give your word. You do the wrong thing you gotta pay - You don’t know...

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: So you don’t feel anything?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No, they deserved it.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: You feel no remorse.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Water under the dam.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Nothing for their families.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I didn’t know their families. Except one... Silence as Frank regards the photo that’s now on top in his hands: One of Jimmy and Frank taken at Frank Sheeran Appreciation Night.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did I have any choice?

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: If you had a choice, would you have done the same thing?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Let’s put it this way, if I didn’t do it, nothing was gonna change. They would've done it anyway. And then done it to me, too... What kind of man makes a phone call like that?

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: What do you mean?  141

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: That’s all I can tell ya. It kills Frank to keep looking at the photograph of Jimmy, but he forces himself to for several more moments. Nothing can dull the guilt he feels for what he did to Jimmy, and as the priest studies him, he thinks he sees something in Frank that was hidden before. Not just remorse, but some faint remnant of humanity.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Would you like to pray now?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: God we come before you sinful and sorrowful, aware of what we have done and what we have failed to do. We ask you to help us see ourselves for who we are, just as you do, and we ask your forgiveness for anything that we might have done wrong, because we know that you are all good and all loving, and love us even when we fail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank sits in his wheelchair in his room, hooked up to a trolley IV, a few faded snapshots in his lap. A young nurse opens the door and comes in to check the IV and take his vitals. As she does it -

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: This is my daughter Peggy. It's the snapshot of Peggy and Jimmy at the miniature golf course. The nurse gives it a perfunctory glance.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Is it. Frank nods to himself.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t think I’ve met her yet.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: She hasn’t been around much.  142 The nurse cuffs his arm to check his blood pressure. And, just making conversation, like she does with all patients -

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: She’s your only child?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I have four daughters.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Really. Frank nods. None of them have been around much. She glances down at the photo again.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who’s that with her?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Who’s that? You really don’t know? She takes a closer look at the picture.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's Jimmy Hoffa.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Oh... She clearly doesn’t know who that is. Frank doesn’t bother telling her. She puts her fingers to his wrist to check his pulse rate. He looks at the next snapshot: Jimmy and himself at Appreciation Night.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You only know how fast time goes when you get there. She’s used to old people saying things that make no sense, and says as much -

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. He looks at her two fingers touching his wrist like a hand of benediction.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Did I have any choice? She gives him the kind of ‘shhh’ you give your kid to comfort their crying. But it’s not that.  143

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: I’m trying to take your pulse, Mr. Sheeran, please don’t talk. Silence as she counts his heartbeats... then takes her hand away and writes it down.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay. You’re free. He looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Until later today (when I put you through all this again).

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I’m here. The nurse smiles and we follow her as she heads out into the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow action in the corridor as we begin to hear the priest giving absolution. Day changes to night. From out in the corridor we're only allowed a partial view into Frank’s room, and even that is intermittently obscured by nurses in white coming past. It's as if what’s going on in there is too sacred to intrude on, the priest’s hands extending over Frank’s head, giving him absolution, the words only sometimes audible over the routine hospital sounds.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: ...through the ministry of the Church may God give you pardon and peace, I absolve you from your sins in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and the Holy Spirit.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Amen. INT. ASSISTED LIVING FACILITY - FRANK’S ROOM - NIGHT We find our way back into Frank's room.  144

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Give thanks to the Lord, for He is good.... Frank doesn’t remember the prayer. The priest prompts him.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: His mercy -

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: His mercy endures forever.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: May He bring you safely to His kingdom in Heaven. Amen.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Amen. The priest readies to leave.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: I can come see you again if you want, after the Christmas holidays.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It’s Christmas?

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Almost.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Okay. I ain’t going nowhere. The priest heads out.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Father, could you do me a favor? Don’t close the door all the way. I don’t like that. Leave it open a little.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Sure. From outside the room, the door starts to close, but then stops just short of covering up our view of Frank in the room.  145 As the priest’s footsteps echo in the hospital corridor, we can just make Frank out in the sliver of light between the edge of the door and frame - alone in his wheelchair with the little stack of photographs in his lap, slowly leafing through them.
